reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Jurassic Park: The Game
Original Release: 2011
Genre Tags: Adventure; Story Rich; Atmospheric; Quick-Time-Events
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 7-11 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Strong narrative advocates; Casual gamers
REVIEWJurassic Park: The Game is a narrative experience set as a sidequel to the original movie.  The actual gameplay is composed of Quick-Time-Events (QTEs) during action sequences and mild puzzles during the plot development sequences.  You wonâ€™t find wild, face-paced, dinosaur-fighting action, but I think any fan of story-driven experiences and/or of the Jurassic Park movie will find this game intriguing.

The heart and soul of the game lies in the story and the characters.  I found the story to be absorbing and the characters to be interesting.  I will admit that I am a little biased because the original movie came out when I was a kid and at the time it was one of the best movies around for my generation.  I really liked how Jurassic Park: The Game was set as a sidequel to original movie and expanded on the events that occurred.

The QTEs are a frequent topic of discussion when people consider this game.  I personally enjoyed it, because there are plenty of other games out there where I run around in with an assault rifle and a bandoleer full of grenadesâ€” so it was refreshing to experience action sequences in an alternate fashion.  I also thought it was pretty cool that there were different cut-scenes depicting the various ways you could die throughout the narrative; this helps make it less annoying and more interesting when you do mess up a QTE.

The game is not without faults, of course.  In fact there are many faults.  They ranged from truly game-faltering, (for example: I experienced UI trouble where my mouse cursor disappeared and was forced to restart), to just annoying, (for example: I had to change the resolution one level at a time, each time waiting for the screen to readjust).  Then there were some things that didnâ€™t really matter gameplay-wise, but still were a little ridiculous: for example, I found it jarring that the character of the aboriginal Costa Rican girl who supposedly grew up on an island was voiced with an accent you would find on a second-generation American Latina from Brooklyn.

Nevertheless, I didnâ€™t find any of the faults to be so egregious that they soured my experience.  I actually rather enjoyed the experience, despite the minor annoyances, and I legitimately remember feeling a little sad when I beat it because it was over.  In fact, I would say the thing that disappointed me the most about this game was just that it was a little shorter than I would have liked, because I was really enjoying it.

I posit that Jurassic Park: The Game is an enjoyable, story-driven experience that will especially appeal to anyone who is a fan of the original movie.  You also should be comfortable with idea of playing a game that relies heavily on QTEs for action scenes.  If you want intense firefights with dinosaurs then you probably will want to look at other games.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
After the first Episode was over I couldn't understand the terrible rap the game gets - it seemed mildly entertaining, if nothing special. Then Episode 2 started and the writing nose-dived...and then got worse. Stupider and stupider as the game progressed: Childish stereotypes; characters behaving preposterously because the plot demanded it to move things forward; dialogue composed of blithering nonsense; people explaining plot points that were then flatly contradicted by events five minutes later. By the end it was a total farce.

The end-of-game credits explained all - they switched writers every Episode, and the guy who wrote Episode 1 wasn't involved in the rest of the game.

Crummy, crummy game - 1 Clunestar out of 5.

reviewText:
So I've seen a lot of bad reviews for this game, mostly complaining about the quick-time event controls. But that's not a problem with the game; it's a problem with the player!
What I'm saying is, if you HATE QTE's, don't buy this game. If you don't mind them and you're a fan of Jurassic Park... well, this is very worthwhile.
In a way this is a four part 'sequal-that-never-was' to the original movie and it captures the feel of JP perfectly.
I really don't think the QTE's are that bad either, they aren't very hard and the game lets you get away with a lot of mistakes.
Really, this comes down to how fussy you are as a gamer and how much money you're prepared to spend on good fanservice.

reviewText:
This Telletale game is certainly not on par with their more recent releases but it is still worth the nine hours of play. The QTEs had me struggling at times but the regular save points make it easy to overcome. I am not sure how many of the choices you make in the game effect the outcome, but I found myself wanting to more at the end.

The different levels of completing each scenario are a nice touch but I can't see what the result is of getting a gold over a bronze, apart from maybe an achievement.

Would recommend, but not at full price, wait for a 75% reduction and you'll have a decent buy.

reviewText:
I love most modern Telltale games, so I started to explore their back catalog. Jurassic Park is the farthest back I've gone (excluding the first Poker Night) and wow, things done changed.

The concept is the same as any of their other point and click adventures. What changed is the interaction system. And it's much worse. They clearly improved things a lot for the first Walking Dead.

The problem comes from the quick time events. The amount of time you have to press them - especially when there are multiple in a row - is a small fraction of a second. This means that to get through some of the harder sequences you have to memorize the order of buttons to press. There's really no other way to move forward. It's super frustrating when there are long sequences with dozens of buttons you have to try to remember. This is just bad game design, as it makes it literally impossible to succeed on your first attempt.

Add to this the fact that you can't skip cutscenes and having to repeat sections quickly becomes a chore. Having to stare at the same low-resolution textures for minutes at a time while you re-hear the same conversations you can't affect is not fun.

The characters also make some really strange decisions that don't seem to fit with how they're established. It's like the writers didn't plan out the ending when they started. In the end, I didn't really care about any of them or what happened to them. And it was quite clear that my choices didn't matter or affect anything.

So Jurassic Park has convinced me to stop going back with Telltale. I won't be trying out Back to the Future. But everything forward of this point is gold.

reviewText:
I am a fan of telltale games, and I am a dinosaur. So I might be a bit biased.

Jurassic Park: The Game is a game that if you enjoyed the film you would enjoy the story of the game. Telltale did a wonderful job recreating the iconic locations of the first Jurassic Park film. It introduced old and new dinosaurs, old and new characters. It continued the plot in regards to the Barbasol can of dinosaur embryos that was stolen the night of heavy storm that led the the dinosaurs going wild from the first film. The game tries to connect the gap of what happened to Dennis Nedry's attempt to sell the embryos for millions and the new characters introduced in this. This 4 episode story and the characters introduced are what makes this game good.

Gameplay is point and click with quick-time responses. This is where I believe the game has the most issue. The quick-time responses are the most annoying, hassle inducing aspect of the game. Especially if you want to 100% achievement the game you will have to repeat a section over and over to time everything. Sometimes though you know what to do a button sometimes did not register or even at time a micro second early or late and you are off for the sequence of events. However, if you can get past this the story and dialogue in regards of the gameplay make up for it.

I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Telltale Games, enjoyed Jurassic Park or enjoy both. Though I had issue with the quick-time. The story and plot and new characters make up for it and make the game a should play""

reviewText: I must say, I love Telltale games. The Walking Dead 1 & 2, The Wolf Among Us, Back To The Future, and especially the Poker Night at the Inventory series - All excellent games that kept me enthalled, entertained and content for so many hours. Being a gigantic Jurassic Park fan and having watched all the movies and read the book countless times - when I saw that they made a Jurassic park game, I couldn't pass up the opportunity to play it. Unfortunately.. this game fails to deliever on so many levels. Yes, they have the music. Yes, they follow the Jurassic Park storyline. And Yes, they manage to do an excellent job at submersing you into the Jurassic Park world. But other than that, it doesn't have much else to offer. The voice acting isn't the greatest, but it isn't the big issue. The big issues are the poorly sequenced context-sensitive timed events, the lack of impact that your decisions make throughout the storyline/game, and the horrendous amount of glitches that severely hinder your progession. Unlike other Telltale games, Jurassic Park makes you tap multiple keys which pop up on the screen for a mere second of time. I believe this is done to show you how many different death sequences they designed for the game (there are oh so many - in fact, they even put in a death counter to show you many times they stuck it to you). Next there is the lack of impact your decisions make. There is only one point in the game where your choice determines whether or not a character will live or die -- this changes the ending of the game, and it happens right at the very end. Lastly, the glitches. I haven't seen a game so mired with glitches after its release since Call of Cthulhu" and "Alone in the dark". I had to restart sequences atleast 5 times in all of the 4 episodes of the game in order to progress through the storyline. Having said that

reviewText:
Before buying/playing this game, ask yourself two things:
1) Do you love the Jurassic Park story? (of course you do)
2) Do you love the Jurassic Park story enough to deal with a whole game being based around QTE-style (Quick-Time Event) gameplay?

If your answer to the second question is yes, then you will undoubtedly love this game for the story quality alone, if nothing else.

The story is based at the same time as the first movie, and it revolves around Gerry Harding (from the first movie) and his daughter who find themselves in the midst of the storm (the very same storm from the movie), who must find a way to escape the island. Throughout the game they come across various problems, which you as the player must solve.

The game is your standard adventure" genre game

reviewText:
One of the primary reasons why the original Jurassic Park film from 1993 is so great is Spielberg's excellent blend of adventure and suspense. One moment you're gazing at the amazing dinosaurs, that graphically, hold up really well today; and the next moment your clenching your buttcheeks as the Trex and raptors are trapping the intrepid explorers in cars, trees and kitchens. Spielberg sucks you in, chews you and spits you out. It's a very immersive experience. Immersion is where the game then misses the mark.

Considering that all of the game's action sequences are entirely played out with quick-time events you're at the game's mercy when it comes to survival. While this would be tense and suspenseful in other game, Jurassic Park: The Game consitently pops a shiny healthbar in your face right before the action begins. Both spoiling the surprise and giving you a reason, other than your survival to play for (namely medals). It draws you out, while a moment before you were still sort of among the creatures of yore.

The immersion breaking doesn't end there. The character models often act and move like poorly articulated puppets, and their props tend to float around in their hands. Furthermore, when they move, they often run straight toward the doorpost in one angle, but safely sail through the door opening in the next. When the action subsides you'll be solving puzzles. By my account I played maybe four actual puzzles and everything else was related to sequential dialog options.

It's a shame though, because the game really thrives when it plays with its source material; showing you sections of the park that weren't shown in the films. It game is at its best at the end, where it fully embraces it's Spielberg roots by going straight back to Jaws. However, on its downtime, it is rather dissapointing.

reviewText:
Jurassic Park: The Game is one of those games you will really enjoy if you were a fan of the films. Telltale the developer, has done a wonderful job recreating iconic locations from the film, and at the same time introducing new dinosaurs with a whole new story. It takes place during/after the events of the first film with a whole new cast of characters, so thereâ€™s plenty of original content for those thinking itâ€™s just a recreation of the film.

The story and characters are at the heart of Jurassic Park. Gameplay is point and click and although fun, itâ€™s nothing terribly interesting that most people have probably already experienced in The Walking Dead (a more popular game by Telltale). The characters are well made and each has their own distinguished personality that fits into the story in one way or the other. Generic is not a word I would use to describe any of them. The story is filled with plenty of unexpected moments and has great pacing while being spread over 4 episodes that will probably take you 7-8 hours to finish.

The game reminded me of the film so much that I just had to go back and watch it again. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has even the slightest interest in Telltale games or the Jurassic Park series. Itâ€™s certainly an adventure to remember!

reviewText: Great game if you are a Jurassic Park fan. It is very short though, 4 episodes total and i spent 6 hours beating all 4 with some paused time and 17 deaths. So I could see this being a 5 hour game for some. With that said you might want to get this during a sale. full price which i Think is 30 bucks is not worth it at all. but if you can get it on sale it is enjoyable. This is only the second Telltale game ive played with this style of gameplay. The Other being Game Of Thrones. So far through 2 episodes of Game of thrones I would compare the two with Jurassic Park being more difficult but Game of Thrones episodes are longer and It has a better story. Jurrasic park is more in your face action packed just like the movie. Jurassic Park also has a bit more of a puzzle element that so far Game of thrones lacks.\n\nTo sum it up get this on sale if you like Jurassic park or the other telltale games of this style. If its not on sale or you are not a fan of the interactive movie type games then I would stay away.

reviewText: This is weird case where I sort of liked it but can't really recommend it. It's incredibly linear, the gameplay is mostly limited to Quick-Time Events, and the story isn't especially great. That said, I thought the characterisation was quite strong for the most part, and while it's not exactly graphically impressive the visual design compensates for it well enough. I got it on sale for $7.50, and I don't really regret buying it or playing it, but chances are you'll find it a disappointment compared to other games by this developer.

reviewText:
Consider this game about a 6/10.  Add a point if you are a fan of point-and-click games, especially those made by Telltale (as am I), and add another point if you are a fan of the Jurassic Park intellectual property (as am I).

The game takes place during and immediately after the events of the first film, and mostly follows Jurassic Park chief veterinarian Gerry Harding as he attempts to make his way off of Isla Nublar with his daughter.  The plot thickens as a corporate espionage scheme to recover Dennis Nedry's stolen dinosaur embryos goes awry, and the few stranded survivors left on the island find themselves hunted by a previously unknown species of dinosaur.

As far as plots go, it's one of the better ones you'll see in a movie tie-in.  Dialogue is surprisingly natural, and the game reuses a lot of hallmark music and sound effects from the films.  None of the films' main characters are featured in the game, but fans of the movies and books will appreciate how Jurassic Parky" the game feels as it tells its story.

Jurassic Park: The Game by Telltale Games is an enjoyable experience
date: but it suffers from quite a few technical glitches and just generally isn't as polished or deep as the company's subsequent masterpiece

reviewText:
First of all I must say I didn't want to buy this game. It came with the Telltale Package" I bought and I gave it a try. I was expecting a "Walking Dead" with dinosaurs but that's not exactly true. The gameplay is pretty similar on the few-puzzles end but with less decision making and more quick time events plus not everything you do has a timer.
QTEs are  a big part of the game so I you don't like them you are going to have a bad time. More so because they are harder than any game I played so far (generally speaking) but I guess they were made this way to add a layer of difficulty and replayability considering every episode has a score system. Perfectionists are going to want to have a gold score on every episode and I don't think it's that bad to die every now and then. But I really wonder if there are people who ace all QTEs on the first try. Camera and character controls are another matter. They are lazy to say the best and exploration is non-existent. There are at best 4 angles in an area and once there you use the keyboard to use the camera. The KEYBOARD!!!
Story is connected to the first movie which is kinda cool and has many well thought references which is cooler and progression is similar to every mainstream story out there. It also has its share of plot twists. The ones near the end are totally stupid and bad guys are even more stupid but I didn't expect much anyway so yeah...
Graphics are exactly like in the screenshots and OK in my opinion. They don't matter much anyway...
Soundtracks are pretty good. Some of them I recognize from the movies
date:
some from every horror movie ever and some I don't know. The movies' original score is used frequently and that's a right choice if I ever saw one.

For me this was kind of a free game and I don't regret playing it. But I wouldn't pay more than a couple of bucks.

+ Soundtracks
+ Balanced difficulty
+ Story references
- Emberassing camera
- Lazy controls
- Lame-â™¥â™¥â™¥ plot twists
- "Bad guys"

6/10"

reviewText:
The story started out great and very promising. Too bad it didn't last long. 3 weeks now, and I've still not completed the game. Finally decided to call it quits when the only character I like went bonkers. Just, no.

+ It's Jurassic Park.
+ Graphic's alright.
+ Voice acting is quite good.

- Story is annoyingly slow.
- Weird characters development.
- QTEs, QTEs, and more QTEs (I don't mind them in games, but not in almost the entire gameplay)
- Unskippable cut scenes.
- Bad controls; sometimes keys don't register during the QTEs.
- And sometimes the mouse cursor disappears too. Had to restart the game every time that happened.
- Irrelevant choices for dialogues in certain scenes.
- Very weird music choices for some parts of the game.

I love Jurassic Park and I wanted this to be good. I can forgive a lot of things if only the story is good. But it's not. Unless you are a die-hard fan of the franchise, skip this. Even if you're a die-hard fan of the franchise, buy this only if it's heavily discounted.

My Rating: 4/10

reviewText:
Difficulty: Just Right
The Bottom Line: Worth Playing/Good
Score: 7.5

Note: This Game Been Tried Out And Reviewed In Offline Mode or On Another Steam Account And Or Consoles.

Jurassic park the game so much promise. I have to say that for the most part, it delivered quite well. Playing is a thoroughly satisfying experience, and the moments of suspense keep you on the edge of your seat. Also, as you play you begin to really have an appreciation and liking for the characters. Story is a Huge part of this game. The graphics are okay.

Gameplay.
The style of interaction can be hard to get used to to, but is rewarding in the end. The distinct impression that I get while playing is that of an interactive movie. While this was what I was hoping for, it might not appeal to everyone. There is a fair amount of puzzle solving

Overall: a great game, a must-have for any JP fan,Especially coming from a fairly independent developer (Not a big-name like Ubisoft or Bethesda)

reviewText: Jurassic Park is the start of the new style of Telltale Games where quicktime events become a major part of the game.  There are puzzles and there are dialogue choices to make like all previous Telltale games, but action becomes a major part of this game series compared their previously released games.  This makes it fun though, it is Jurassic Park and action is to be expected.  You'll have to evade the T-Rex, run past the Raptors, and save yourself from a death-defying roller coaster.  The storyline is fun since it occurs simultaneously as the original Jurassic Park movie, expect that here you follow a different group of children and Park workers who are trying to survive the breakdown of the Park.

reviewText: When my daughter asks for a dinosaur game, I know just what to play. This game is really great. Once again, Telltale makes a great game that wants to be a movie. Personally, I feel they should have used this game story for a movie sequel. The story is much more believable than the sequels were, and I really like the characters. The characters grow and change through the game, so be prepared to change loyalties. Most of the game is played through choosing conversation options and the quick time events. You are graded by performance, so make sure you make the right responses and have a quick trigger finger because it can cost you. The game looks good and the soundtrack makes good use of sounding like a Jurassic Park score. You'll hear all your favorite themes from the film, but not so much that it sounds like they ran out of ideas. The only complaint is that the game can lag. The game wants to be a film, and sometimes there is a pause between sequences. It's like when the DVD skips momentarily. It doesn't really hinder gameplay, but it can be a minor annoyance. Also, the mouse pointer may disappear, but that can be fixed by just reloading the segment you were at. These two glitches did not keep me from enjoying the game and I am working on another playthrough just to get the rest of the achievements and play for a slightly different outcome. If you liked the movie Jurassic Park, I am certain that this game will not disappoint.

reviewText:
You know other Telltale games like Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us? Well, this one is a lot like them but has way, way more quicktime events. Storywise it's as solid and as atmospheric as the other ones.
In the Jurassic Park cosmos 'The Game' is the settled very close to the first movie and tells a parallel story. Some scenes happen in showplaces of the movie but no characters from the Spielberg picture will appear in the game. Technically is pretty much the same as TWD+TWAU -> same engine, same controls, same level of voice acting

In a comparison between TWD, TWAU and JP I'd still say that this one is the weakest but it's a very good game nonetheless and better than the second season of TWD. Telltale Game players can't do anything wrong buying it... as long as you haven't already reached your limit of quicktime event tolerance with the others games - 'cause there is one for nearly every interaction in JP.

7/10

reviewText:
I heard some really bad things about this game, but I enjoyed the original 3 films (well, 3 was okay), so I thought for $4.99, why not see how bad it is?

I was surprised.

To begin with, this is one of TellTale's (The Walking Dead, Wolf Among us, Tales from the Borderlands) earlier efforts, so if you go in expecting a deep story or emotions, you won't find it here, not that it's shallow, but it's pretty basic...but that said, I had an overall good time.

I would say, that I wouldn't buy it at full price, it has some issues. Being Telltale, they of course have quicktime events, and I used the keyboard, and sometimes I KNOW I pushed a button only to have it fail, and others I didn't push it, but it still counted, so it can be frustrating at times, but it didn't happen every time. I will say it seemed less forgiving than later titles.

The game picks up sometime during the first film, but none of the characters show up, not really anyway. There are 4 episodes in total, and some achievements that are missable, if you are into that.

You do get some dialouge, but it's not quite like later titles where it really affects anything, it's more or less just there for flavor. The characters aren't horrible, but nothing to write home about.

The action scenes are overall well done, and the use of quicktime can lead to some tense situations, but as I said, the only issue is sometimes it won't register properly leading to frustration with the system.

You get to control a few characters, and you meet the expected dinos and some not from the films. In the end, it's a decent action/adventure game, but not with a deep storyline.

I'd say get it on sale, then if you don't care for it you're not TOO much upset over $5. If you liked the movies, you'll have an overall good time, and if you like achievements, there are some you can miss but you can load certain parts of an episode to get them again, and you will mess up because of the quicktime event format.

reviewText:
After the Back To The Future game Telltale Games decided to throw in an adventure game that is the direct follow-up to the first Jurassic Park film. And what a hell of a job they did!

What's a Telltale adventure game?

Telltale specialises in adventure games that are easy to complete and usually almost all achievements can be obtained in just one go. There's a great emphasis on immersion hence the many cutscenes and the QTEs incorporated into them.

They can usually be completed in 8-10 hours and there are numerous scenes where a choice can be made - this may result in the sacrifice of a character or it can affect the ending in various ways. Inventory is usually limited to a couple of items - there's no abundance of puzzles and those found throughout the game are easy to complete.

What's their Jurassic Park game like?

As said this is a direct follow-up to the 1993 film Jurassic Park. There are returning locales and references to many things, thus, if you are a fan of the JP films this game is a must for you. The new scenes and characters are also very interesting and we get to learn some new things of InGen along the way.

The game is a tad bit more difficult than the rest of the Telltale games. First of all, QTE have to be timed more precisely and more quickly. It is common that you make mistakes and the game has an evaluation system for this - gold, silver and bronze levels can be attained. Gold levels indicate no slipups - you can only obtain a handful of achievements by not making any mistakes.

The scenario" menu gives you the ability to return to some of the QTE events to give them another go. This is a must if you want all achievements obtained as no slipups are a must to have 100% completion. In fact
date: there are some conversation-related or easter egg-like achievements throughout the game. Some episodes must be completed again from beginning to end to really see everything that is intended to be seen in this game.\n\nThis time inventory is non-existent and walking is not possible with characters. Instead the icon in the lower-left corner of the screen indicates if there are other locations (rooms) to visit in one scene so we click on these instead of making our protagonists walk. Sometimes clicking on objects is not enough but we have to drag the mouse while doing so - a nice way of interacting with the game's world but a bit too tedious. Telltale games released later on shed themselves of this system and became easier to complete. Oh
recommended: and no choices exist to affect events later on in any form.\n\nAll-in-all
hoursPlayed: Telltale's JP game is pretty exciting and it is a must for the fans of the JP franchise as well as for fans of Telltale's adventure games. You just have to get yourself over the not-too-refined QTE system and here and there the game has some audio issues and a somewhat mediocre engine not always offering nice scenes to look at.\n\nStill
voteText: with a great discount it is an easy grab especially with the oncoming Christmas sales."

reviewText:
QTE Nightmare: The GameThis pile of garbage is basicly a poorly written fanfiction, infested with â†‘â†‘â†‘ ridiculousâ†“â†’ amount of â†â†“ Quick-Time Events â†â†â† that makes you want to pull your hair out.

Let's start with the plot. The story takes place after the events of the first movie, the Park is overrun and a small group of survivors is trying to escape from the island. The characters are not particularly interesting, in fact the only reason you'll remember them after finishing the game is because their unimaginable stupidity. The events feel forced and most of them happen, because someone is doing some dumb â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

The dialogues are so poorly written, that each time a character opens his/her mouth, you feel like they are reading lines from a pÃ³rn movie. Worst of them is the Costa Rican SeÃ±orita who speaks in half English and half EspaÃ±ol so you don't comprender what the que demonios she's saying.
Yes, you guessed right: Telltale didn't bother to translate Spanish speech for you!

Last but not least we have an absurd amount of QTE. Most of them require a less than a second response time and result in instant-death if you fail to mash the correct buttons.

Overall this game is not only a waste of time but a waste of the movie license as well, because there is way more potential in . The only redeeming qualities are the achievements, but the moment the last cheevo pops up I'm almost 100% certain you will Alt-F4 and rush for the uninstall button!

PROS- Only 8-9 hours long
- Has slightly better animation quality than your average Telltale game

CONS- Incoherent plot and nonsensical events
- Bland characters and poorly written dialogues
- Bad voice acting
- Ridiculous amount of frustrating and non-intuitive QTE (there's a LOT of them!)
- Bugs! Cursor tends to disappear after a QTE event, forcing you reload the checkpoint and redo the segment again, because you're unable to progress without knowing where to click. Oh, the joy!

reviewText:
I recently purchased the Humble Telltale Bundle, after having thoroughly enjoyed The Walkind Dead: Season One as well as both of the Poker Night games. When Jurrasic Park was announced as one of the two bonus games, I was stoked because I loved the movie when I was a kid and at this point have fallen in love with TTG's newer adventure games.


That much being said, I was met with dissapointment. The writing does not feel like it captures the same passion Telltale had with other games (the stories in The Wolf Among Us, Tales from the Borderlands, and The Walking Dead all feel very compelling and can draw you in even if you aren't a fan of the source material already). The voice acting is top notch, but the writing itself just isn't there so far.


The quick time events have become incredibly intrusive and distracting, with many of them not making a difference whether or not you fail (an example being when you nearly run into the other main character while driving to the visitor center, which has an identical outcome regardless of if you make the QTE in the very short time it gives you).


On the same subject of the over done QTEs is also the fact that this game has possibly the worst controls of any Telltale adventure. You are all over the keyboard, and many of them have very strict timing involved or you will fail. Also, the steam overlay will occasionally make the button prompts dissapear (which has so far only happened to me on keyboard, and not controller).


The graphics are not mindblowing, but they do what they need (as is typical with these games), however it is much less stylized than the other TTG titles, when it really could have benefitted from more of a traditional TTG art direction. Also, there is no silent pause like the other TTG games have, and the pause screen that is in the game is incredibly loud and obnoxious (t-rex roaring every couple seconds).


Is this game playable? Sure. Would I recommend it? Only to die hard fans of both Jurrasic Park and TTG. I would recommend pretty much any of the other TTG games over it, with Tales from the Borderlands or The Wolf Among Us being my primary recommendations. Jurrasic Park just lacks the polish and soul that simillar titles from the same studio have in extra-large helpings.

reviewText:
Telltale games, the studio that gave us Sam & Max, Monkey Island, Back to the Future and of course not to forget the Walking Dead. Jurassic Park, like most other Telltale games is a point-and-click adventure that has 5 episodes that guide you through the story. Based on the blockbuster movie franchise: a small group of people and scary nocturnal predators that are hunting the group.

The story takes place after the events of the first movie. The game begins with an unknown woman that is running away in a dark jungle, from some scary, unknown creatures with shiny eyes, she is being chased of a cliff. Barely surviving the fall, she ends up on a road, while an oncoming car is heading straight her way. From there the story skips back to earlier that day with a father and a daughter overlooking the peaceful jungles, searching for dinosaurs. In one interesting scene a fight breaks out between a Triceratops and a T-rex, while the main characters have to dodge and run from the crazed fighting giants, not trying to get squashed and trampled. The game is story driven, enjoyable and very thrilling and exciting at times.

The game is 2/3 watching quick time events and 1/3 easy puzzle solving. At times it feels like watching a 5 hour Jurassic Park movie. There is not much exploration or hard puzzle-solving. There is no inventory and a short five hour play through. This game could be more considered as an interactive movie, which some of you might really enjoy (I am one of them). Fans of the film might also enjoy this game, for its familiar locations, and its â€œrealâ€ looking dinosaurs. If you enjoyed the movie Jurassic Park, you will enjoy this â€œgameâ€ for sure. A fun fact: there are a couple of dinosaurs that were not in the original movie.

It is possible in this game to make the wrong decisions, or fail a quick time event. During the quick time events, dinosaurs jump from the bushes, after which the player has to press a sequence of buttons to either dodge the attack or miss and end up being torn to bits by his fangs or claws. It is hard when you are so involved in the cut-scene and sitting at the edge of your seat, to keep paying attention to the required button sequence. You have no choice but to finish the whole sequence again before you can move on, which can get in times very frustrating. The game has two different endings.

Pros
- Beautiful cinematic sequences.
- Nicely animated dinosaurs.
- Interactive movie experience.
- Thrilling action.

Cons
- Precision button pressing can be frustrating at times.
- Linear.

Score:
7.8

reviewText:
Very buggy and badly in need of some serious polishing, Jurassic Park: The Game shows a lot of potential, but feels more like an Alpha release than a finished game. Several times I had to reload a scenario because the mouse cursor or option to switch scenes simply disappeared, even if I was half-way through the scenario.
Despite playing it on a good laptop from 2011 (the same year as the game was released), and the fairly mediocre graphics, the frame rate was consistently low and often fairly laggy. The story was well-presented and quite interesting, but the characters (especially Nima) were bland and flat.
What really killed the game, however, was the Quick Time Events. I don't have a problem with QTE's, and having them as the main gameplay mechanic works quite well when the game you're playing is essentially an interactive movie, as this one is, but these QTE's are handled so poorly that it just ruins the game. I don't know if it was the result of the bad frame-rate or lag, but I lost count of the amount of QTE's that I matched perfectly only to be told that I had got one wrong, or the times when I had to press three different arrows in the space of less than a second, thereby resulting in multiple deaths and forcing me to replay the same sections over and over again until I had memorised the fairly long sequences of button-presses rather than relying on actual digit dexterity, which is the whole point of QTE's in the first place. As the game is, it is literally impossible to pass a large number of the QTE's on the first or even fourth try.
Save your money and get some of Telltales later games instead.

reviewText:
I just finished the first episode on my PC and I can honestly say this is another very well done adventure that TT has given us. I'm just judging it based on the PC version and not the iOS. Other then a couple of audio glitches (repeat dialogue, echoes while outside) that occured during gameplay I see nthing wrong with this game. I know some people are put off with the lack of free roaming you can do, as you simply switch scenes instead of physically pushingthe analog stick (I played with a controller) to reach there. But really, it's not that big a deal as you do much more interesting combos of context actions.

The story is set during the day of the first movie where everything goes to hell. You control multiple characters left in the park for reasons very connected with the film (a mercenary waiting to take the DNA sample that Wayne Knight's character never delivered and a dino vet and his young daughter (this may be the only child character in JP I don't want to feed to the T-Rex). The tension is palable, the voice acting is up to par with other titles and the dialogue and story (as well as relationships with other characters) keep you engaged.

If you are a fan of TellTale's other more recent games likeThe Walking Dead, Wolf Among Us, Tales from the Borderlands and Game of Thrones and you liked any of the JP films (especially the first one) there is no reason not to buy this, especially if it goes on sale. One episode in and I'm having a blast.

reviewText:
The reviews are true!  If you liked the movie, you'll like the game.

The storyline for this game is extremely well written.  It takes place during the first Jurassic Park movie and ties in with events and scenes that you will remember.  Tell Tale's point and click interface is not quite as finessed as it is in The Wolf Among Us and The Walking Dead, but I found that if you just mash the buttons you really can't lose.

You don't buy this game for the gameplay, you buy it because you love Jurassic Park.  It's like watching a whole bunch of left-out footage and storyline that didn't make the cut for the movie.  I'm glad I tried it out and I enjoyed it.  It really does extend the magic of the movie.

reviewText:
Jurassic Park, the franchise that gave me my love for science, for history, and for dinosaurs.  The books, the movies, all of it defined my childhood.  My mother once hid the movie, because she got sick of rewatching it over and over again.  Like any other Jurassic Park fan, I picked this game up to give me more of that Jurassic Park Experience, and I was not disappointed.

First, the story:  Iâ€™ve read nearly all of Michael Crichtonâ€™s works, from Andromeda Strain to Micro.  And I must say, this game nearly perfectly captures Crichtonâ€™s writing.  The crooked get their comeuppance, not all the heroes live, the question of â€œshould man have this power?â€  I do, however, have some gripes.  The pacing was off on occasion, and there were quite a few â€œex machinaâ€ moments (LOOKING AT YOU TOUR CAR).  There were also a few deaths which could have used more explanation.  However, the story did remain fresh, interesting, and expanded upon the movies very well, tying a lot more into the books.  8/10 for story.

Second, the Gameplay:  Really, thereâ€™s not much to say here.  Itâ€™s a Telltale game.  You QTE, you solve puzzles, you talk to people.  But the game was varied enough to keep me from getting bored.  7/10 for gameplay

Finally, the overall feel:  Despite what many people are saying, this game is amazing.  The story is tight paced, the characters are wonderful, the gameplay isnâ€™t too boring, and the sounds/voices are perfect for the game.  I would love to see future games like this.  My total score is 8/10, HIGHLY RECCOMEND

reviewText:
I like how this is a parallel storyline to the first movie, and how they succeeded in not interfering or messing the original up. No spoilers here, because this is actually a good game in that respect if you're a fan of the franchise.

The biggest problem I had was keystrokes not registering and, and this is a real gamebreaker for me, the inability to stop playing and pick it back up at a later point. This might need some explaining, but basically this is what happened; While in the story, I got stuck in a level solving a problem, so I returned to the main menu and tried to restart that specific part. But it was locked...so I tried replaying the part that came before that, and when I finished that part, it didn't continue the storyline but instead returned me to the main menu...which means I have to replay the entire chapter...

There are some other little nuisances, most of which are about the very linear storyline (although certain fight scenes can have different ways of playing out, as long as you don't die) and trouble with the controls, but mostly the fact that at some points I got too focused on the controls that the environment just became a blur, I didn't catch half of what was said and missed just about everything that was not an arrow pointing in a direction with a green circle shrinking to indicate the required timing.

This is, however, like I said, a really good story running parallel to the original first movie and it is reasonably executed. As such I believe it does deserve a recommendation.

reviewText: Do you like QTE's intensely? reviewText: When the reviews stated that the game was filled with quick time events, I imagined something along the lines of Resident Evil 4. But no, this game is only quick time events there is no actual gameplay. It is like watching a boring long winded B movie version of Jurassic Park made up of cutscenes, just waiting for the opportunity to hit Up, or maybe Down or sometimes Left at the right moment. Fail to get it right and the cutscenes repeat again until you do and believe me that gets really repetitive and boring very quickly. You miss a lot of the QTEs too because sometimes you forget that you're actually playing a game as there can be such a long time between interactions.\n\nAll in all the graphics are OK, the story is boring, and the gameplay is non-existant. Indeed if you really want to get a feel of the gamplay. Just put any of the Jurassic Park movies on, grab an Xbox or other controller (it doesn't have to be on) and when a dinosaur appears on screen and a character is in peril,  just hit B or X on the controller to dodge. If you feel you weren't quick enough, just rewind and try again. That is this game in the nutshell.

reviewText:
My impression of this game is pretty mixed, but I wouldn't recommend it to most people, and certainly not to the less hardcore players who may have the patience to work their way through the game.

The main reason for this is that a very large part of this game consists of QTEs (Quick Time Events, where you are required to hit a given button in order to perform an action within a given time interal), and these QTE sections are genuinely quite frustrating to play through -the interval for pressing the buttons is incredibly short. I suspect it is often as short as a fifth or a quarter of a second, which is frankly absurd. I often don't even have time for my brain to register which key I am supposed to press before I have failed the task. This is compounded by two other problems - these QTEs are often chained together into sequences of several QTEs where the icons are layered over the top of one another (so you cannot see the next button in the sequence until hitting the current), and they are utterly unforgiving -  a single failure will result in the death of a character, and the sequence will need to be started again. There have been instances where I have had to repeat sequences 15+ times, and learn the keypresses by rote in order to get past.

This said, the story and characters are reasonably engaging, at least for the first two episodes - the game is at it's best when delivering narrative on a scene by scene basis, or when it has small logic problems for you to solve. The writing however takes an utter nosedive by the time you reach the third and fourth episodes, which are also QTE ridden nightmares. By this point in the game the source material gets thrown under a bus in order to pad for content (there's now a geothermal powerplant in an underground volcano base that will explode if not dealt with, wtf?).

Some other elements are massively over used. The T-Rex as an example seems to conveniently teleport around the island and is present in a significant part of game, appearing in every other scene to allow for lengthy, annoying QTE sections that just waste your time without adding anything to the narrative.

Overall, there could have been a decent game, and the first episode was genuinely entertaining if not a bit rough around the edges. It rapidly devolves into frustrating nonsense however - I suspect the developers were running out of time and as a result quality really slipped.

reviewText: I was really very impressed by this game. The usual point and click approach of collecting an inventory full of junk and rubbing the items together till you solve the puzzle would have just killed any kind of tension and not fitted with the atmosphere of the film. It is instead a mix of simple puzzles, conversation sections and reflex sections that are kind of like a simplified version of Heavy Rain. These work really well and it avoids getting frustrating as you can make some mistakes without being killed, it just affects your medal. Also if you are repeatedly getting killed it will reduce the difficulty for that section. The story line is good, it fits in a lot better than most of the film sequels. The graphics are pretty good compared to other Telltale stuff but still have room for improvement; there are a fair few bizarrely contorted facial expressions. The inclusion of medals, achievement and two alternate endings give this more replayability than standard point and click games.

reviewText: Not a point and click adventure game by any means. Most of the exploration is replaced by Heavy Rain-esque quick time events. These can get somewhat frustrating quickly as they become pseudo games of memorization and Simon Says. The exploration and quick-time event gameplay isn't terrible, per se, but it could be much improved on and leaves a lot to be desired from the standard point and click adventure game fan. Otherwise, the plot and voice acting, as well as some particularly exciting cinematic sequences within the game, more than make up for the less-than-stellar gameplay. Took about 5 hours for a full playthrough of the game. Try to grab it for $15 or less if possible. 7/10.

reviewText: I'd say this is a good game for super fans of the franchise.  It adds some fun new lore concurrent and immediately following the first movie.  As a game, however, it probably leaves some to be desired.  The gameplay is primarily quick-time-events, so your participation is basically hitting buttons at the right time after on screen prompts.  You also get some dialog choices, but as far as I can tell it barely affects the story.  That said, I really enjoyed it, and had fun watching the story unfold, running and fighting dinosaurs, and trying to get a gold medal on each level.  The story being only about 7 hrs long, I'd save this game for when it's on sale.

reviewText:
If youâ€™re really into the Jurassic Park-universe, then I highly recommend this game. Itâ€™s funny, filled with puzzles and explorations.

Youâ€™ll get the chance to see the locations of Jurassic Park and see it from angles you havenâ€™t seen before. You even get to see parts of Jurassic Park that are mentioned in the book, but for the first time you get to actually see them! I wonâ€™t spoil that you get to see though!

What is Jurassic Park: The Game with no dinosaurs? Youâ€™ll run into T-rex, raptors and other dinosaurs mentioned, but never seen before.

The plot of the game really revolves around the Barbasol can and all the ramifications created by Dennis Nedry. So this game is for Jurassic Park fans since it respects the original Jurassic Park story and adds more to the Jurassic Park-universe.

You also get to meet Sarah Hardingâ€™s little half-sister; Jessica Harding and her father; Gerry Harding â€“ he was present in Jurassic Park at the Triceratops scene!

Peace.

reviewText:
If you're bummed that the PlayStation 3 exclusive Heavy Rain never received a PC port, then Jurassic Park will have to do to satiate your hunger for a quick-time-event (QTE) driven game.

For those unfamiliar, QTE gameplay places a heavy emphasis on reflex. Players are prompted to press a series of buttons on screen and failing to do so swiftly and correctly will lead to disastrous consequences. Jurassic Park: The Game is built solely upon this foundation and nothing more.

Despite this, Telltale still brings to life the world of Jurassic Park. Every dinosaur encounter is suspenseful and both the plot and characters are the very least, interesting. Unfortunately, the game is marred by several bugs. Audio tends to fade in and out sporadically and frames drop at specific sequences.

I applaud Telltale's attempt at venturing into more mature territory. With the nerves to show a teenage girl being eaten by a T-Rex, this studio has proven that they can push the boundaries.

Grade: B-

reviewText:
Its shorter than previous Telltale games, but they changed up the game play dynamic, steping away from the random clicking of objects to move the story on.  Now theres timed events and skill button hitting.  If you fail you die.  I loved this improvement in the Telltale way of gaming.

But this is about all I liked.  The story was mediocre, rather confusing, repetative, and a bit far-fetched in parts.  The graphics were ok, a bit glitchy and I ran into a few lag/repeat events.  For this game to be delayed as long as it was (6 months I think), I feel they could have improved in that area.  I dunno if Spielburg or Universal put their foot down on somethings but something doesn't add up.

Overall, its an ok game.  Get it on sale cheap.

reviewText: This is my favorite of the pre-Walking Dead Telltale games I have played, but it is still flawed. It's basically a ~4 hour QTE fest with some more traditional adventure game puzzles thrown in. One rather obnoxious feature is that some of the QTEs were not consistent. For example, if multiple buttons came up at the same time, sometimes it was a choice, but sometimes they were all required. This cost me multiple achievements, which often require perfection. I'm not sure I'll go back and replay sections just to clean that up. I enjoyed the story, but the lowest common denominator graphics really hurt when there's a Wii version. I like that Telltale can actually be serious, which gives me hope for the Law & Order game. Sam & Max does nothing for me, and even Back to the Future seemed more corny than any of the films. And dinosaurs make everything better.

reviewText: If you're a Jurassic Park fan, eh, for a budget price of $7.50, why not? Telltale fan? Not sure, really. For a Telltale game, the mechanics are very clunky, and oh, did I mention that this game is riddled with quick time events? Not to mention some of them being nigh impossible to get through - some QTEs require you to press directional buttons in a sequence, but only the current button required is shown to you, which makes it rather difficult to go though the sequence. But fear not! Spamming buttons also works as well since pressing a wrong button doesn't penalize you in any way.\n\nHonestly, this is one of the worst games Telltale has ever made in a while. The only reason I recommend this game is for its story, while not amazing, is pretty good, and can entertain you for about... let's say, 10 hours?

reviewText:
Oh, come on. Why am I seeing so much flak for this game? This is better than half the games you'll get out of an indie-bundle, and those get praised and noticed more than a 'mediocre' game like this. Yes, it's a low-budget game, but Telltale did a mostly great job with their resources. The only thing really wrong with this is the unforgiving QTEs and slow scene transitions when investigating.

The thing is, for a Jurassic Park GAME, this is the best we've gotten besides maybe that GBA park-sim. This captures the feel and experience of the first movie with a group of well-rounded characters and a fairly enjoyable plot twist. When people inevitably die, you aren't just watching a dino eat, you're watching someone you cared for disappear. It's a small element the movies lacked, which along with the strong plot puts this above the second and third ones. The first movie still holds strong in being the main attraction, but this tie-in fits right alongside it as a desert to any fan. Just don't go in expecting a proper video-game, and be ready to practice a few sequences two or even three times before the game will let you continue to watch itself unfold.

If you're a Jurassic Park nut, buy it. If you're a casual fan, pick it up when it's on sale. If you are neither, this game might not have much for you. Still, it's a fact that there's tasty meat hiding inside this flawed package, and it's probably scared of the nasty T-Rex riding the bandwagon.

reviewText: This is a very story-driven game.  The story is solid and the dialogue is good.  I found most of the characters somewhat unlikeable, though.  The gameplay consists of a mix of pressing the right button at the right time and some logical, but pretty easy puzzles.  I wasnt very fond of the timed button pressing, but it did fit with the actions of the scenes, and if you miss the buttons multiple times, the game makes it easier to do (eg, you might only have to press one button instead of two or three at that same time).  Rounding out the interaction is the dialogue options and exploring the environements.  The graphics are decent but nothing special.  Both the voice acting and music are excellent.  Overall, it took me about 6 or 7 hours to complete.  If you like Jurassic Park, or like games with a solid story, it's worth it, but I would wait for the price to drop to $5-10.

reviewText: If you're a Jurassic Park fan who enjoys getting as much backstory as you can, you'll enjoy this game. It's a very cinematic feel, but the graphics are choppy at times. Such examples are items being held are slightly off (like a knife attached to the outside of the hand instead of it being in his grasp) or audio repeating itself at a key point (locating objects with the binoculars). If you can get past the glitches, it's an enjoyable game. Some of the characters are a tad bland, but Dino-fodder is probably the reason for it. All in all I enjoyed it and would reccommend it to anyone that is a fan of the series. Now if only we could get Jurassic Park:Operation Genisis on Steam! That would be something!

reviewText: Just finished the game. I honestly loved every minute of it! I was really immersed in the character interaction, the tense moments, and the general awesomeness of Jurassic Park itself. The gameplay (Quicktime events) honestly isn't great at times but the story is really fun to watch unravel. I was pleasantly surprised at how much fun the game actually was! I spent a lot of time re-loading scenes trying to get the best possible score due to the game not responding to my inputs during the QTE's. But in the end it was worth it, because the story was just so damn fun. The game throughout just had this charm that kept me playing.  Oh, and it works perfectly fine on Windows 8.

reviewText:
This game gets way more negative criticism than it deserves. Yes, the game pretty much consists of dialogue wheels, looking around the environment for clues, and lots of quick-time events as you're being chased by dinosaurs, but if you approach it less like a traditional video game and more like an interactive cinematic story, it's really enjoyable. The story is intriguing, the characters are likeable, the environments and the dinosaurs look great, and a lot of the action scenes are really thrilling. I'll admit, I jumped quite a few times while playing this.

My only major complaint is not with the amount of quick-time events in the game, but with the fact that some of them are nearly impossible and require lightning reflexes and several tries to complete. There were times when a button would come up, and before my brain could even register what button to push, I'd miss the cue, trip over a rock, and get eaten. I would say only about 5-10% of the QTE's in the game were that frustrating though, while the rest weren't too difficult. It was annoying at times, but not enough to ruin my enjoyment of the game overall.

If you're a fan of the Jurassic Park movies, do yourself a favor and don't miss out on Jurassic Park: The Game. As long as you can overlook a handful of frustratingly difficult QTE's, you'll be in for a fun, suspenseful, exciting, and visually pleasing cinematic adventure.

reviewText: Hey, screw you, man!  I like Jurassic Park, and I liked this game!  You wanna fight about it?  So what if it's a sloppy, choppy game of QTE after QTE after hard-to-see-because-it's-at-the-other-side-of-the-screen-and-blends-into-the-background QTE, gnoamsayin'?  It's fun, it's thrilling, it's even pretty dumb and 70% of the Cavalry episode is pointless filler.  Confusing segue.  Spotting the often clever movie references is oddly satisfying, too.\n\nIf you're a fan of JP, and QTEs don't make you want to murder the entire gaming industry in heartless rage, you might care to check this game out--and then hope they make more, b/c 6 hours is not long enough, tbqh.  Hopefully with a bigger budget.  And gosh dang, I'd prefer if the game wasn't riddled with Telltale's goofy characters and writing, but, you know, it's kind of endearing at some points.  The kid was a surprisingly good addition, reminding me of Goosebumps & wotnot, which made me feel even more nostalgic and fancy.

reviewText:
In the beginning, I was not very interested n this game, I received it on a gift and day 1 I would not be able to get it to work right. I chucked it aside and never looked at it again, yesterday after reinstalling I gave it another go and I guess they patched it because it worked fine. I thought the beginning of the game was somewhat weak but soon enough I began to enjoy what I saw. I personally like the story and the characters though I do not care for the 15 year old girl and I believe I have let her die one too many times but ill break down the good and the bad in my opinion.

The Good:
Decent story that goes more in-depth as time goes on
Some scenes really keep you on the edge of your seat
Dinosaurs feel natural and have some nice animations and head movements some of which is funny and humorous as well.
The Death scenes are hilarious.

The Bad:
QTE's, this game is filled with them so expect to have to deal with them a lot.
The voice acting is the worse I have heard in a telltale game with frequent cut offs
Sometimes Scenes transition before they are done being played out.
Very annoying bugs in episode 1 which lasted for one scene after which I never saw said bug re occur. The bug itself was having to re listen to dialogue play out after it had already done so.
Stupid new dinosaur hybrid added in to add more depth but felt like an exaggeration and stupid idea. The look of it makes me want to laugh than be afraid, you will see what I mean.

In conclusion, there was a lot about this game I enjoyed. I have sunk almost 8 hours into this game and am nearing the end of episode 4 and I can say the time was not wasted. Bought at a discount price, this game is very much worth it in my opinion.

I would recommend this Title without a doubt. Sit back, cook some popcorn, mix a drink and enjoy the antics of Jurassic Park!

reviewText: Delayed, but reviewing it anyway. Using the famous 'point and click' adventure from BACK TO THE FUTURE and THE WALKING DEAD, JURASSIC PARK: THE GAME is a satisfying experience, provided you can sit through the serveral issuses that plagues the game. Despite it's limitations, it's pretty entertaining, despite people wanting a 'dino shoot-em'. Think of it as an interactive film, as it allows you to control the fate of the characters you play. Even with the occasional bug here and lag there, JURASSIC PARK: THE GAME is an all right game, sure it's not perfect, and if you really wanted to know what happened to Nedry's shaving cream from the first film after the Dilophosaur attack, this game is for you, especially if you're a hardcore fan of the franchise like myself. If not, please resume playing Turok/Dino D-Day/Carnivores or anything else.

reviewText: I started the game from the 1st episode screening through a projector on my wall lying on my bed playing with a gamepad & ended it. As at this time we are hearing of an upcoming film being made: Jurassic Park 4, this was an appetising opening act.\nSure, it is like they say with fumbling controls; but the story made it worth the excitement almost like watching a Jurassic Park film that I had never watched before (having watched 1,2 & 3). Indeed, apart from basic similarities, it was different (introducing Dennis Nedry) and refreshing, preparing me in awe for the upcoming film! If it was more like the films than it already is (minimally) I may have been upset as the handling was really quite fickle, I endured the acrobatic controls to enjoy a NEW story now rather. I enjoyed the game on the wall instead the big picture took so much of the frustration caused by the controls away! Game on.

reviewText:
Being a fan of almost any game that involves dinosaurs and a fan of the Jurassic Park films I loved this game, the storyline links well to the series of events that occur during the first Jurassic park film with accurate references showing that once again TellTale games definately do their research!

Being a game that relies almost entirely on quick time events they are not for everyone as some parts prove challenging to maintain a steady flow without messing up, and messing up just once often leads to your death. The short reaction time that is expected in some parts can be daunting but it is humanly possible, you just gotta be in the mind set for fast reactions.

You are given a rank at the end of each section, depending on how many mistakes you made during it. The ranks are Gold, Silver, Bronze and nothing. Gold requires no mistakes throughout the section, silver allows for 1 mistakes to remain in the silver rank, bronze allows 2 mistakes to keep within the rank but at 6 mistakes overall you don't get a medal for that section. Some sections you automatically get gold for simply playing through it, for example during a section based around the speech choices you can get gold as there is no mistakes to be made.

The achievements in this game are creative and unique, some involve exploreing the surroundings, some require taking the shortest path through characters discussions whilst other require making no mistakes/not dying during an entire playthrough!

Overall I would recommend this game, it is exciting, interesting and extremely enjoyable.

reviewText:
I do really like this game. Some may call it linear, some may call it a Quick time event compilation, but i think its a stellar point and click game. Its never too hard to a point that you need to look up a Guide but (most of the time) also not to easy. There were really difficult Puzzles though. Doable, but hard. Aside from the point and click parts you have the other Elements that this Game offers. First, the Story. Here is where the Quick time events come in. There are gonna be people that wont like these parts but heres the deal:

Bad Quick time event: Come right the hell out of nowhere and can cause cheap deaths.


Good Quick time event: Gives you enough time to react, you expect it and it overall is placed better.


I think this Game has the GOOD Kind of Quick time events. When there is a point in the game that uses this it shows you because there then is an icon at the upper right corner of the screen. At first its a Gold Rank (T-Rex). If you miss one little move that isn`t fatal, it turns silver (Triceratops). If you then miss 2 more times, it becomes Bronze (Dilophosaur). As you can guess, this is kind of a rating system of how well you did during these events.




Verdict: I think that this game is overall very good. Flawed, but good. If you like Jurassic Park, then buy this now. What are you waiting for? ITS JURASSIC PARK! The story is especially great for fans of the movie because it basically takes place during the events of the first film, but here the focus is on other characters created for this game.
If you havent seen the movies, you can still play this game but you probably wont understand a lot of the references (theres quite a few!). Overall, Good Game.

reviewText:
I was going to write a review earlier, but I decided to wait till' I beat it. Here we go, review of Jurassic Park: The Game!
*que jurassic park theme*
Graphics 10/10: For a telltale game, since this was made in 2011 im saying this from that years graphic standards, and it looks pretty good, with only occasional lag spikes, but when they happen they simply just pause the game, although not the music.

Music 7/10: Now I know what your thinking, OMFG WHY YOU RATE JURASSIC PARK THEME SO LOW OMFG IM REPORTING YOU TO STEVEN SPIELBERG, no im not rating the Jurassic Park theme that low, its the music made by the developers im talking about. It is still great, and it catches the overall atmosphere of the game JUST under perfect.

Gameplay: 8/10: I have to say, sometimes I enjoyed watching the characters talk more than playing the game, because of one reason in 3 words; QUICK-TIME-EVENTS! Seriously, it makes you press 2 different buttons in the same sequence AND you dont even know what the next button you need to press IS until it pops up onto the screen, and by that time you have about a quarter second to do that! The quick time events I enjoyed is where you need to keep pressing the same button over and over again until the meter is full, and also the parts where you have to concentrate by moving your mouse into a moving circle for a couple seconds.

Overall 8/10: Its a great game for Jurassic Park fans, especially BIG fans like me, (srsly I own almost every dino game on steam), it would be ok for telltale fans, but if you don't take part in either of those communitys, DO NOT BUY IT! Only do that if your bored and looking for a short adventure. Great overall! Have fun blasting through Isla Nublar!

reviewText:
Great and worthwhile storyline. 8/10
If you are a fan story driven games with Quick Time events, it's a decently well put together.
The added bonus with the few puzzles in the game that don't feel out of the way and pointless.
Granted most of the times your not horribly rushed but when you fail to many times the quick time events change up a little to help you get through the story.

Everything pulled from the original Movie just fall into place through out the story of the game, a few details feel a bit of a stretch but that are expected backstory and character development.

Though everything about the game is a normal play experience from dev like in most of their other games, So expect plenty of Quick Time events and replaying failed Quicktime events.

Worth while little story and expecting to go back to play through again soon in hopes I don't die as manytimes again.
Last playthrough was death tally 19 times, gaming time spent for a first time playthrough was 7 hour's

Worth While purchase even after getting it discounted from Green Man Gaming.

reviewText:
English version (wersja polska jak zawsze niÅ¼ej)

Have you heard the stories about these guys who, during the Jacksonâ€™s LotR shows took out the books and loudly complained (from the first rows of the cinema) that Tolkien had it different? Well, back in the day when Jurassic Park entered the cinemas I was that kid who quite loudly argued that â€žthese are not velociraptors but utahraptors!â€ or that â€ždilophosaurus didn't do that!â€. Consequently I had a rather biased approach towards this game. Even more so that by the time of JP's release Telltale had managed to completely destroy (at least in my opinion) another brand that was very precious to me: Back to the Future. Truth be told, while I didn't have that much expectations, this game has still managed to make me give up playing a time or two. And then I have returned because, well, dinosaurs.

Speaking of which, not all of the dinosaurs present in the movies (or, particularly, the first one) made it into the game. While there obviously are raptors, triceratopses and T-rex (still glorious!) there is no single diplodocus or brachiosaurus, which I can not forgive since the brilliant scenes in the first movie featuring these dinos. Furthermore, I get the impression that raptors do not get enough screen time. Telltale also introduces a few species not present in the movie. No spoilers, but they could have chosen better.

Another point that I want to make is that oftentimes the scenes featuring dinosaurs are plain stupid. Let me give you an example from early in the game when one of the protagonists tries to push a triceratops out of the car's way. With his own hands. You sure know the triceratops? The huge, heavy, thick skinned, three horned Cretaceous rhino? As a layman I know not to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ of rhinos (not like there are that many where I live, but still), and the said person trying to push away the dinosaur is an employee of the park, consequently I'd expect some basic expertise.

It doesn't much help that most of the protagonists of JP can be easily placed on the sliding scale of plain boring to idiot. The dialogues are also not as polished as in the studio's newer titles. Admittedly, around the fourth episode things liven up a bit and some of the characters get more interesting (usually for one or two lines of dialogue). According to the credits, different episedes have been written by different people, which sometimes results in characters acting completely differently and incongruently throughout the game.

Bugs and glitches also deserve a paragraph of their own. First of all, Telltale games have never been particularly well optimized and this might be the worst of them all. I have tested JP on two different machines, both well above the suggested requirements, and on both the game often stops for a second or two while, for instance, changing the camera position or in the MIDDLE of a quick time event. This is particularly irritating due to the fact that QTEs are not very well timed. Usually the game does not give enough time to react which results in learning the key sequences by the heart.

To sum up: there is a big list of issues I have with this game. It clearly lacks some polish and gameplay testing, characters are bland, dialogues boring, story both silly and predictable. Truth be told, I'd love to see JP the Game released now, by the experienced Telltale that have developed and perfected their style.  As for now, I may recommend this game only because of, well, dinosaurs.

reviewText:
I'd had this one in my collection for a while; but never really got around to playing it due to a lack of time/interest. That was, until I recently watched the original movie in 3D and got hooked on the series again!

The Jurassic Park Game IS the icing on the cake for the trilogy, It ties up some loose ends and answers some questions (whilst creating new mysteries while it's at it). My Favorite part being when we meet the Velociraptor from Movie 3 and learn how it gets the Gash in it's eye.

The gameplay is quite repetative and gets stale quickly, I mean there's only so many quick time events I can do in one sitting (and I played through the whole game in a single 7 hour block), but you often find yourself overlooking this gripe because of the brilliant story telling methods and sometimes jaw dropping/startling encounters.

I would highly recommend trying for 100% achievement completion on this title, even if it means using a guide; as you get a lot more details out of the narrative and find some pretty cool easter eggs that sometimes blow your mind.

While I wouldn't recommend this game to everyone, Fans on the series will love this title and even new comers to the series will get a kick out of it occationally, and hopefully inspire them to go watch the fantastic films

Bias Score: 4.5/5
Actual Score: 2.5/5

reviewText: Being a huge Jurassic Park fan since the 90's, owning this game was a must. The story to this game isnt bad at all, it has some fun tense moments that I wish the films included. However the only huge downside I had to this game was that Telltale changed up the mechanics of this game with those â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing annoying arrows. So it had some really frustrating moments when you had to hit (sometimes predict) what keys to hit, if you messed it it would lower your overall situational score from gold to silver to bronze to nothing. If you died so many times, they made it easier after so many messups. Story wasnt too bad but it wasnt exactly the BEST. If you can handle watching Jurassic Park III, then you can handle the story in this game. Wait to buy this game while its on sale for at least $7 or under. Overall, the worst Telltale game I've ever played. I'd expect more coming from the developers of The Wolf Among us, The Walking Dead, and even Game of thrones. However, it wasn't a bad game for any true hardcore Jurassic Park fan must own, just gotta have a high tolerance for annoying characters, slow story, and annoying â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing controls.\n\nT-rex encounters > overall game

reviewText:
So just to clear up the game has the same style of looks as The Walking Dead series of games by the same company Telltale games. I have no idea whether is plays the exact same i.e. same set of ontrols and gameplay as The Walking Dead as I've not played that yet so can't really ompare it.

Jurassic Park the game is loosely all QTEs so its a bit terrible in that department but all in all it has a brilliant storyline and does its best to fill in the plotlies left in the first movie like what happened with the shaving cream can that Dennis Nedry drops dring his attack from the Dilophasaurus? It also shows more people who are also stuck on the Island whom of which are one of the vets and his daughter.

So despite its gameplay mechanics which normally appear to quickly and making your stoach be on the recieving end of  Triceratops horn I would recommend the game to anyone who is a fan of the movies and is looking more to storyline than gra[hics or gameplay.

reviewText: As a fan of Jurassic Park, I was quite intrigued by this game. I'm not a huge fan of how it's designed...clicking on arrow keys to see if you escape from a dinosaur or not isn't all that exciting, for instance.
