reviewText:
I really, really want to be able to recommend this game, but I can't. I'm sorry, I just can't. I love Telltale games and I have absolutely no problem with well made episodic games; to me, they're like really good books that can be read (or played through) every so often just for an enjoyable story line and interesting characters.

Not so with Jurassic Park, unfortunately. I'll start with the premise and the positives though...

This game is beautifully conceived and rendered; the premise was too tantalising to ignore. It is set immediately after the first Jurassic Park movie; Hammond, Dr. Grant and the others have just escaped the island in their helicopter. You play as a rag-tag group of characters consisting of other people trapped on the island by the storm, the group intent on stealing the dinosaur embryos and the mercenaries/rescue teams sent in to extract the survivors. It answers all sorts of questions and follows up several interesting threads from the film, like what happened to the dinosaur embryos Nebry stole - okay, in the film they were apparently buried in the mud by the storm, but this covers what happens when the can is found again. One of the characters you play as is Dr Harding, the vet who was treating the sick triceratops in the film, so there is some really nice crossover and continuity.

The graphics are stunning and there are some fabulous extra touches, like unlocking journal pages from one of the scientists which muse upon issues such as why the velociraptors are three times bigger than they should be; why the therodpods don't have feathers as they should, why the dilophosaurs spit venom when they shouldn't, and why the T'Rex's vision is based on movement (okay, it's all mainly to do with Dr. Wu screwing things up with frog DNA, but it's still interesting!).

So far, so good, but then the game runs smack into a solid brick wall of mediocrity that it cannot overcome no matter how much you want it to, despite being a die-hard Jurassic Park fan and the â€œOMG WOW!â€ factor that it's got DINOSAURS in it and how can DINOSAURS not be COOL?!

So what's the problem? Unfortunately, there are many.

First off; the characters. Not one of them is particularly likable or even consistent in their personalities. You end up really not caring what happens to them, which ruins your investment in the game completely. You kind of wish that they would get eaten by the dinosaurs - in fact, I spent much of the game thinking I'd rather be playing as the T-Rex, because I'd have really enjoyed ripping the heads off the irritating mainstays. And theyâ€™d have deserved it.

Secondly, the controls - I nearly put this as number one just because the controls are awkward, irritating, badly executed, inconsistent and downright frustrating. The lack of a decent control interface makes the game slow, clunky and repetitive as you find yourself playing through the same short section over and over because one little mis-click has you dead in the jaws of a T-Rex and when you've watched that same cut scene three times over you find your frustrations mounting - it's one of those games where you find yourself shouting at the screen, such pearls as stop dying and start running
recommended: many expletives. I tried playing with both keyboard and mouse and a control pad and neither worked properly.\n\nThirdly
hoursPlayed: the story line. It's... it's okay. Well

reviewText:
K I recommend this game to anyone who loves dinosaurs, and liked the previous movies. Overall the story is pretty interesting, and there are tense points in the game.

HOWEVER I'm sure all of you guys realize at this point that this game is a point and click. It does not seem like that was their intention from the beginning or something because this is a very poorly executed game of this sort. I can accept point and click adventures if I like the story but sometimes this really gets ridiculous. It switches perspectives WAY too much. You're listening to a really heated coversation between a veterinarian and geneticist about how the woman is a madman, and you've been choosing dialogue options for the veternarian. OK, not that bad, although I just wanted to sit back and watch this.

But then you make me choose the dialogue options for the madman? IN EVERY SINGLE â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ CONVERSATION YOU HAVE TO PICK THE DIALOGUE OPTIONS FOR EVERYONE EVEN IF ONE OF THEM IS CLEARLY â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING INSANE AND YOU MOST OF THESE DIALOGUE OPTIONS YOU WILL NOT LIKE! What the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥? Really poor design. I can't side with the madman at all so you're literally forcing me to pick nothing. I'm glad this game flopped because they deserved it for designing this game so poorly. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing dumbasses.

OH YPIEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE I GET TO GO THROUGH A SCENE WHERE I HAVE TO PRESS TIMED LEFT AND RIGHT FOR THIS CHARACTER WHO APPARENTLY IS TOO â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING STUPID TO WALK ON HIS OWN, AND GOES THROUGH A â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ 15 SECOND LONG CUTSCENE BERATING YOU FOR HIS INABILITY TO WALK. YOU GUYS ARE SO â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING STUPID, WHAT THE HELL WAS THIS GAME? The developers who made this game were so â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing stupid and should be jailed for the controls in this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥cuking piece of motherâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game because I love the newer Telltalle Games but after episode 1, it just disappointed and became a huge yawn. It's very buggy and laggy, scenes don't playout smoothly where character models jump around in a glitchy manner and every once in a while the cursor disappears completely.

What I really hated most about this game is that I hated all of the characters, and you're suppose to play and choose dialogue for almost if not all of them. Which is confusing because I both hate them and want them to get eaten ASAP but the game expects me to choose good choices. It's very confusing and contridating.

Many people complain about the quicktime events but honestly, I look forward to them because it was both really action packed and super exciting to play through, as well as it prevents me from falling to sleep to the sounds of their boring â™¥â™¥â™¥ conversations. I think the most interesting conversation in the whole game is the one between the dad and the little girl... and that's not even part of the main game, it's background dialogue. The voice acting is awesome but damn was it a chore to get through.

Excusing my rant, don't get this game. Only get Telltale's games from The Walking Dead and up.

4/10

reviewText: I don't often feel inclined to write a full review on a game, but for Jurassic Park: The Game, I will make an exception. The reason being that I AM A HUGE JURASSIC PARK FAN. If the same is true for you, then you will love this game. If not, then you will hate it because its not really that good of a game. It's that simple. The entire game, from story, to music, to jokes is fan service and to be getting a new JP game 18 years after the movie released is just an awesome experience! Rating for a Jurassic Park fan = 8. Rating if not = 5

reviewText:
Rating: 5/10
Overview: Interactive Movie with quick time events


The Bad:

- One quick time event after another

- You can dodge a T-rex ready to bite you simply by rolling out of the way.

- You can outrun a velociraptor and T-rex on foot

- You can stop a dinosaur from biting you simply by grabbing its head

- Dinosaurs are not very threatening

- Terrible characters and awful dialogue

- Music and Sound glitches

Conclusion

One of Telltales first games and it shows. Luckily if you want a Jurassic Park fix simply watch the first movie, you will have a much better time. How anybody on the development team thought the scenarios with these dinosaurs were good is beyond me.

reviewText:
Very weak from gameplay perspective - no freedom at all, you cannot even move your characters, it's just a mediocre horror movie with LOADS of QTEs forced into it - you sometimes have to do QTE to just walk!

Boring story with very weak stereotypical characters.

Poorly optimized - games lags and stutters at ending of each scene. It looks much worse than newer TT games, yet it plays slower and weaker than them.

Not playable without controler - mouse cursor dissapearing each time you go to pause screen. Try to do cursor-oriented QTEs without seeing a cursor...

By far the weakest game I've played from TellTale. Avoid.

reviewText:
To all Jurassic Park & Dinosaurs fans, this game is right for you... The best thing about this game is it has a complete set of new story line which is really awesome and thrilling from where the movie left with the canister of dinosaur embryos. The game consists of 4 chapters with hours and hours of fun game play. The graphics are good (Dinosaurs are made well matched to the movie with extra Dinosaurs) and different genre knows as Point-and-click adventure, role-playing which is not bad. You will get killed too with different awesome dinosaur kills =P Epic dinosaur battles Triceraptors vs T-Rex which is available only in this game. Perfect environment and weather conditions feels drizzling and feels went back to Dino times. Characters are appreciable & well made. Variety of dinosaurs including water Dino Tylosaurus (Which I always wanted to see) , Classic T-Rex , Dilos & Raptor. This game has 2 Climax! Lots of dialogues and variety of scenes according to what we dialogue or decision choose. Personally I love this game a lot. You earn medals gold, bronze or silver according to your game play (Death Trolls) and achievements. Sounds effects are impressive. Overall a decent game for blockbuster movieâ€ Jurassic Parkâ€.
Welcome To Jurassic Park

reviewText:
Pretty solid game, can be played both of keyboard+mouse or gamepad, personally I think the gamepad's gameplay is a lot harder.

The story is pretty linear, not enough branches but playing through it once is enough experience. Re-live the Jurassic Park movie in good graphics, it fills that emptiness of lacking dinosaur games in the recent years. I thoroughly enjoyed the hours I've spent playing this game.

Character development is alright, the player gets to make decision for pretty much everyone.

The game's fairly difficult in terms of reactive gameplay, it will definitely improve your reaction time and allows you to make clutch plays better in other games. I'd be surprised if anyone consistently scoring Gold throughout the game.

The game has interesting puzzles that you have to actually put into effort to solve (or trial and error if you prefer to not do the brain work at all)

A fair bit of jumpscares from time to time.

The only improvement I can think of is the continuity of dialogue/speech/action getting cut off/skipped and the accidental ESC press will bring you to the main menu with delay.

Overall it's another damn good game from Telltale. Worth it.

reviewText:
I saw a lot of negative reviews everywhere on the web and i was very sceptical before buying it.
But I was not disappointed !
First of all, yes, there is a lot of QTE and you cannot really control your characters. However, i see this game more like an interactive movie (but a lot better) and the QTE allow the players to be implicated when the action begins.
I can guarantee that you will feel your heart beating when the dinosaurs chasing you.

IF you are a big fan of the jurassic park franchise, i recommand you this game because you will learn a lot about the Park itself and the dinosaurs who was not present in the movie.

IF your are not a big fan of jurassic park, the game could be boring and not very interesting. But try it if you can !  (i am not very fan of QTE myself)
There is a lot of fan service and if you LOVE jurassic park, i am pretty sure that you will love the game.

I can guarantee that you will feel your heart beating when the dinosaurs chasing you.

IF you are a big fan of the jurassic park franchise, i recommand you this game because you will learn a lot about the Park itself and the dinosaurs who was not present in the movie.

IF your are not a big fan of jurassic park, the game could be boring and not very interesting. But try it if you can !  (i am not very fan of QTE myself)
There is a lot of fan service and if you LOVE jurassic park, i am pretty sure that you will love the game.

reviewText:
As a note, do NOT purchase this game with the hopes that it lives up to the quality of The Walking Dead series. Jurassic Park is one of Telltale's older titles, and as such, it shows it's age. The story itself was very interesting, especially if you are a fan of the Jurassic Park world. There are iconic scenes from the films, and the whole story focuses around the can of shaving cream Nedry stole.

The game is good if you enjoy story, however, if you're not exceptionally fast with your keys, expect alot of deaths. I encountered no bugs, however, the game requires you to use multiple keys in quick time sequences. Many of these dont make sense, and include triple tapping and then finishing with another directional. The quicktime scenes are unforgiving, and sometimes the keystrokes fail to registered.

The game also suffers from some lag. It's not very optimized and many of the textures look like garbage even at the highest resolution. Expect lag, regardless of your setup.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely underrated. If you're a Jurassic Park franchise fan, you'll definitely love it. Why? There are so many references to the original JP movie and the second The Lost World movie. You can hear about John Hammond's nephew Peter Ludlow, you can read a special journal which creates supreme logical explanations about the movement-based and binocular vision difference of Tyrannosaurus Rex and extreme big sizes of Velaciraptors because they were actually smaller according to paleontologist, besides Utahraptors and the venom spitting demeanor of Dilophosaurus and what happens to Isla Nublar after the first movie. Meeting with Sarah Harding (Ian Malcolm's girlfriend in The Lost World) was also a nice detail.

Using John Williams' score for the game? Telltale nailed it here. Awesome job.

I went to see Jurassic World a week ago and the I watched the first 3 movies like 50 times in my life and I started playing this one and now I'm completely overwhelmed by the magnificent aura of Crichton's creation. Jurassic Park is my childhood, period. 8/10 for my final score, the only frustrating part of this game is the action sequences with annoying controls. I was obsessed with taking Gold Rank on every chapter, so my playtime went to like 9 hours.

reviewText:
When I started to play Jurassic Park: The Game - Telltale Games, I remember when I was a teenager and went to the cinema to watch this magnificent movie. A world of myth come true with dinosaurs. I remembered the dino fever that this film created in every corner of the planet.

Playing this game was a good thing, good memories came back and I really enjoyed. despite the negative reviews this game has, I could enjoy the idea of the game. Here you play while everything started to go to the disaster. Also, I could read Jurassic Park book by Michael Crichton, wich I highly recommend.

Introduction

Here you have the chance of playing several characters, something very common at Telltale game series. First, you play the introduction with Nima, a mercenary paid by  Dodgson. You remember  Dodgson, that guy talking at the beginning of the film with Gendry, the IT guy. Of course, we all watched the movie and knew what happened with Gendry. Nima has to get the Dino embryos, and that not gonna happen so easily. In the meantime, she finds other members of the Nublar island.

Also, you play with the Harding family, Gerry, and his daughter Jess. remember Hading, the veterinarian at the movie? Well,  the same. He invited the girl that last day for an educational experience, with will be a little complicated.

The idea of the game is not just exploring the island when the electricity goes down and other interesting things happen wich you have to investigate. In the meantime, running away from all perils of a  full dino island.

Like all Telltale games, more than a graphic adventure is more like a visual adventure movie, you can have the chance of changing some things but not always. Maybe some ends but if something is meant to happen, that gonna happen. Of course, you'll have the chance of interaction between characters, each one with a  very well made personality, so that's a good one for the scripters.
The game explores other things the movie doesn't. Of course, I'm not comparing the great Jurassic Park with this game, but I think the game has their good things. I think the people of Telltale read Michael Crichton book to take some ideas from it.

Here you have scenes to complete, and the game saves automatically after each one. Depend if you make mistakes or not, you can reach gold, silver or bronze status. remember Steam achievements if you like to complete them.
I highly recommend saving every time you can just in case. There are very hard scenes and saving will be a useful tool.

Art and Music

For a game made at 2011 maybe the cinematics would be better but I think the game, in general, is quite good. The landscapes well make and the dinos are good. Could the game be better in this aspect? Yes, of course. But I have to mention about the music. Is never disturbing, just great for the action scenes and with that reminiscence of the great John Williams creation for the original movie.

Final thoughts

A good game with a good story. I read other comments about the game and I don't understand why they say about phrases out of context or something like that. I think the game has the Jurassic Park spirit. I watched the movie at the cinema, I watched the movie again several times and I read the book. I think it has the spirit. That island had a lot of things to explore, and having the chance of creating over the created is just awesome. telltale did it so I give an 8/10 for this game. I enjoyed playing it!

reviewText:
It pains me to give a Telltale game a bad review since I've loved all the ones I've played so far but this doesn't even feel like an adventure game. It feels like one very long and very broken QTE.

The control scheme on this game is horrible especially in action sequences. Mouse + keyboard just feels awkward in this one as opposed to other Telltale games like BTTF, Sam + Max, Puzzle Agent, etc, etc and the 360 control scheme is severely out of whack. The game will post on screen instructions with button presses supposedly in north/sout/east/west fashion, but I've seen multiple insances in just the first couple of minutes where what's displayed for what you would think the west (X button) is actually the north (Y button). The prompts aren't displayed long enough before the time runs out to decipher the wonky on screen display and hit the correct button and you end up like a bull in a china shop crashing through the scenery instead of getting it to do what you want. Then it becomes a memory game where you restart and try to time everything with the correct buttons while completely ignoring the OSD prompts

I've been playing a lot of Telltale games lately since I never got around to them and am really enjoying them for the most part, but the controls in this one are very off putting. Very disappointed with this one. I don't like having to muddle through a game over simple timing and OSD issues

I wanted to like this game. I really did but it's just an exercise in frustration and is unplayable from a basic control standpoint

reviewText:
I can say that Jurassic Park: The Game is TellTaleâ€™s lowest point in their game development â€“ however, that is still a testament to the acceptable quality of their adventure games.

Jurassic Park plays more like an interactive movie than an adventure game â€“ more like Heavy Rain than Monkey Island. Everything is broken into quick time events, with relatively long gaps in between action segments. Failing an action sequence oftentimes results in death, which then requires you to backtrack to the previous checkpoint in that sequence and try again. The load times are very fast and you can jump into the action once more quickly if you happen to miss an important button press, but the repetition of these moments gets stale after the first episode. Still, Iâ€™d get on the edge of my seat every once in a while as I raced to fill up button press meters to run from a T-Rex.

Jurassic Park is not a very long game â€“ only four episodes, making it one of TellTaleâ€™s shorter adventures. The dialogue and voice acting is solid enough, though they attempt to give fans a wink and nudge by implementing lines from the movie (â€œHold on to your buttsâ€¦), though they just didnâ€™t mesh right and were executed similarly to corny catchphrases. I found a surprising layer of depth to the mercenary characters, however, the more I started to think about their motivations for being on (and eventually leaving) Isla Nublar. Iâ€™m also hoping that the character of Nima wasnâ€™t meant to be sympathetic, as I found her to be annoying and her presence jeopardized or killed many people around her.

The game is buggy, in a few surprising ways. Dialogue lines would repeat on me in my playthrough, and during some action sequences some of the button prompts would not appear on the screen at all when I replayed events. It also isnâ€™t a very pretty game â€“ the overall look is stylized similarly to The Walking Dead or Back to the Future, although it is utilized far better in each of those games.

It certainly isnâ€™t the best adventure game to be released in the past few years, nor is it a must-buy for Jurassic Park fans. Overall, the game is worth playing through on a Saturday afternoon just to experience another TellTale game, but the current Steam price is entirely too high. This game is only worth about $10 or less, ideally. Anything more than that just isnâ€™t worth the price of admission. Recommended if youâ€™re looking for a quick adventure game, and this game just-so-happens to be on sale. Otherwise, itâ€™s entirely skippable.

reviewText:
As a fan of the Jurrasic Park franchise and Telltale studios, I was excited to pick this game up on the steam sale. After my first few hours, I have lost most of my interest in finishing this title heres why:

1.) Story- Even for the Jurrasic Park fan, the story feels painfully average. It's not terrible especially when compared to the plots of some popular titles,but for a game that wants you to point/click/qte through the game, an average story is less than acceptable.

2.) Cheap difficulty- I hate games that hold your hand making everything simple, but just as annoying are games that make themselves hard through gimmicks. In this instance, the gimmick is the QTEs. There is little rhyme or reason to the button sequence, some areas have several buttons spammed in succession where even ninja reflexes would struggle, and you have less than a picasecond to respond before the prop is considered a failure; in some cases you don't even see a prompt. When the consequence is just not getting a perfect ranking, this is fine, but when you spend over an hour dying and rebooting because you can't hit wda swd as d a w s in under 2 seconds flawlessly that's just garbage. Some might say well use a game controller instead of mouse and keyboard, but in my experience with both, there hasn't been a difference.

3.) Bugs: I have had to quit and reload the game several times because the mouse will randomly just disappear which makes a point and click adventure impossible and some QTEs impossible to pass. When the only solution this wonderful community has found to constantly work is quit and reboot it's just obnoxious.

reviewText:
One could think of this as the bridge between old and new Telltale. The puzzle solving elements of it are still intact, but are not nearly as challenging as they were in Sam & Max and Back to the Future, and are wedded to the dialogue and quick-time events that the newer games have. The thing is though that there is a big difference between the QTEs in Jurassic Park as opposed to a game like The Walking Dead. In Jurassic Park it's way more difficult to hit every single prompt and are more of a game mechanic than something to build tension. Sure, failing some of them can kill your character but in general you don't have to hit many of them to advance the story. You complete each scene with a Gold/Silver/Bronze ranking and you need to hit every prompt to get the gold, which nearly gave me autism as I was felt compelled to immediately repeat every scene that I didn't do perfectly the first time. I ended up seeing a couple scenes three or four times just in one playthrough.

I should also mention that this game is kind of buggy. The gameplay is fine for the most part- it's the menus that are the problem. Several times I would pause the game and when I unpaused it the cursor had turned invisible. I had to restart the game and play the scene from the beginning to get it to come back. It's been a while since I played the game so I can't remember the specific issue, but some of the options on the menus are labelled strangely and it's easy to accidentally start new games or restart a scene you're already some ways into.

Overall though, I think this game got too bad of a rap when it first came out. The QTEs are hard enough to be fun (you can even beat the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out a raptor hand to hand if you're cool enough) and the story was pretty solid.

reviewText: Like some of the other reviewers, I can't say that I didn't like parts of the game, but overall there's no way I can genuinely recommend it. The story is probably it's biggest selling point because it really is kind of cool to nerd out and learn about some of the other dinosaurs that weren't heavily featured in the films, and it helps that the voice acting is, for the most part, pretty great. I think I learned a lot about myself as a person when I discovered that my favorite character in this endeavor is actually trash. What kills this game for me are the clunky controls with the QTEs. I've played other TellTale games, so I had a general idea of what I was getting into when I bought it, but I honestly wasn't expecting it to be *quite* that bad. Playing with a mouse and keyboard, there were times when no matter how quickly I mashed the keys I still managed to screw something up, and this game is generally not forgiving of that at all; sometimes a single slip-up is all that's standing between you and a dinosaur eating your face. If you're looking for a fun and diverse game you're out of luck. Unless you're looking to experience all the diverse ways you can be murdered in a dinosaur theme park, in which case this is an A+ simulator. If you're going to buy it because you're a die-hard fan of JP or TT, I'd recommend waiting for it to go on sale again. I picked it up for $5 around the holidays, so I can't be too upset that I don't love it.

reviewText: Like some of the other reviewers, I can't say that I didn't like parts of the game, but overall there's no way I can genuinely recommend it. The story is probably it's biggest selling point because it really is kind of cool to nerd out and learn about some of the other dinosaurs that weren't heavily featured in the films, and it helps that the voice acting is, for the most part, pretty great. I think I learned a lot about myself as a person when I discovered that my favorite character in this endeavor is actually trash. What kills this game for me are the clunky controls with the QTEs. I've played other TellTale games, so I had a general idea of what I was getting into when I bought it, but I honestly wasn't expecting it to be *quite* that bad. Playing with a mouse and keyboard, there were times when no matter how quickly I mashed the keys I still managed to screw something up, and this game is generally not forgiving of that at all; sometimes a single slip-up is all that's standing between you and a dinosaur eating your face. If you're looking for a fun and diverse game you're out of luck. Unless you're looking to experience all the diverse ways you can be murdered in a dinosaur theme park, in which case this is an A+ simulator. If you're going to buy it because you're a die-hard fan of JP or TT, I'd recommend waiting for it to go on sale again. I picked it up for $5 around the holidays, so I can't be too upset that I don't love it.

reviewText:
A great story from Telltale, as you might expect from the developer. The characters were rich and the story was enticing. The only big let down from this experience was that very few (or maybe not any) opporunities arose to make meaningful decisions or game changing determinations. I have grown to expect these from Telltale and was therefore slightly dissapointed.

However, the game is still well worth its price on sale. This game has the appeal of a book you cant put down and the action of a movie that makes you stuff your face with popcorn while wearing a wide-eyed expression on your mesmerized face.

Dont expect it to be a long game. Quality is king here.

reviewText:
Well just finished this game and i think it was overall a good experience, however the game has it's flaws.

The gameplay is pretty minimal, all you do is solve minor puzzles and press keys under time pressure. But what telltale games lack in gameplay, they make up for the storytelling and cinematics. You play as different characters and get a chance to explore their past and personalyties. Unfortunately the game is pretty linear and there are only 1 choice in the game that truly matters, although it kinda feels like all of them do.

I also played this on a macbook pro retina and experienced some technical difficulties with the full screen mode where the screen was completly black and i could not do anything. After some research i figured out that there is no fix on this issue, but it was still possible to play the game in windowed mode. So if you have a Mac and wants to play this game, be awere that you might have to play in window mode, but it is not such a big deal and I still managed to enjoy the game.

Overall i think this was a great game mith a good story and it is also cheap, I had a good time playing and defidently recommend this game.. especially if you are a fan of the other telltale games.

reviewText: Ungodly boring. The characters are annoying and two-dimensional, the music drones on and sometimes wipes out the dialogue in an unholy war of audio-dominance that threatens to leave me deaf, and the only good thing are the dinosaurs (if and when they're not being â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ized into puzzles or props). The only worthwhile thing in this is the dinosaurs, but somewhere along in the game they suddenly became extinct in favour of boring and mindless puzzles that would have no use in real-life. I quit at the time that Doctor Alan Sorkin (in female form) decided to treat the water of the animals to break their lysine deficiency, even though we all know that in the second movie that although all the dinosaurs were given that very deficiency they still lived on on Site B, rendering the conveluted puzzle of herding Parasaurolophus' mind-numbingly idiotic. I end this disappointed review with an agreement with one of the characters in the story by the name of Oscar, whom posited that he simply knock out the insane Doctor Sorkin before she makes us play one more god damn puzzle.

reviewText:
I struggled with whether or not I would recommend this game. In the end. I think the cons far outweigh the pros. 6/10

Pros:
1. Decent storyline
2. Good voice acting, although it was bad at times
3. Jurassic Park nostalgia
4. Nice continuation from the first movie
5. Some interesting scenarios...

Cons:
1. and some bad, bland, and uninteresting scenarios
2. Mentioned above... the voice acting had rough patches
3. Storyline, although decent, felt loose and less fleshed out than I thought it could have been
4. Characters and personalities were kind of annoying, never really shined
5. The quick time events felt unresponsive at times and even unfair

While I love most things Jurassic Park, I can't add this to my list of recommendations. This one can easily be skipped. You wouldn't miss much. Sorry Telltale games, you've made much better!

reviewText: Jurassic Park: The Game isn't all bad, IF you like Jurassic Park. Once, finally getting over the slow pace and repetative action sequences, I found myself soaking in the familier settings of the iconic films that I grew up watching. Whilst it is a different story being told to you, it's familiar enough to keep you interested and intrigued in playing through the games some 7-8 hours of game time. This is not game that will be to everybodies liking, but if you enjoyed the films and you've fell in love with the universe that surrounds 'Jurassic Park'. Then this is worth having a look at!

reviewText:
OK, I read through the negative reviews and I don't quite understand what the fuss is all about. Granted, I played through only Episode 1 so far (at the time of writing) but I must say, to my surprise, that I thoroughly enjoyed the game! Of course, the controls can get a bit difficult at times but this should not take away how good the gameplay story is. I played through the Walking Dead and Back to the Future games by Tell Tale and this game is on par with them.

Moreover, this is one of the few games where I enjoyed losing because in most cases (as far as Episode 1 is concerned) when you lose, you can see your player being eaten by the dinosaurs! I found this very funny but I don't recommend small children watching this! It could give them nightmares!

I heartily recommend this game to Jurassic Park fans and players who love point and click games.

reviewText:
I really liked Telltale's previous big franchise adventure games, Back to The Future and, especially, The Walking Dead - and since I've always liked Jurassic Park, I figured that this game would be right up my alley. Sure, I'd read the warnings in form of poor (I mean, *really* poor) reviews for this game... but I figured that, given my previous happy encounters with Telltale added my interest for Jurassic Park (who doesn't love dinosaurs?), it would still be fun. I figured that even though it might not be great, it could still be a good enough game. I mean, how bad could it be, right? Well, as it turns out: really, REALLY bad.

Let's start with the actual gameplay: there isn't much of it. The story pretty much unfolds by itself, merely prompting you to hit the right buttons at the right time (which, at times, is an absurdly frustrating and pointless task). You can't explore as in other Telltale games, there are no choices to be made and you're generally just viewing an interactive movie. Which, even though it's a letdown compared to other Telltale games, could perhaps work... if the story was better.

And that brings us to the story: while not bad per say, it's not something special, either. The story in itself is decent, no more, no less -  but it's supported" by crummy dialogue and unlikeable and unlikely characters that are
recommended: pretty forgetable. And you constantly switch between them in a fashion that makes you not really know who you're controlling at times
hoursPlayed: going from fighting a character at one moment to controlling the former enemy at the next. And there's no way to skip dialogue or any of the counbtless cut scenes... so when you die (and you *will* die) due to missing one of the gazillion reflex button hits
voteText: you're often forced to sit through the same scene again and again.\n\nAnd the bugs... oh dear. The bugs in this game forces you to constantly exit the game and

reviewText:
A low point in games from Telltale Games.
After Sam & Max and Tales of Monkey Island games another approach was taken, adventure and puzzles were replaced with quicktime events and timed button presses. In this game the sequences and timing are often flaky, sometimes more sensitive and sometimes less but equally annoying.The story is not that special either.
For a fan of adventure games I wish they had retained classic adventure and story telling that have worked so well.
I understand the need to try something else but this should have got more design and gameplay development before releasing. Not recommended unless you are a fan of this kind of games or just want to collect games.

reviewText:
Welcome To Jurassic Park

Who doesn't love the Jurassic Park movies, They're great, well the first one was great!
and luckily, Tell Tales Jurassic Park Game picks up where the events of that first and finest movie left off.
And keeping in mind that Tell Tale make great adventure games, expectations are high as we enter Jurassic Park.

You plan to have dinosaurs on your dinosaur tour, right?

When you fire up the game you're thrown straight into the action.
You'll find yourself running through the vegetation of Isla Nublar with a dinosaur snapping at your heels. A few button presses and tumble off the edge of a cliff later and the screen fades.
Ahhh, now we've switched characters and the opening credits roll as we listen to the familiar and excellent Jurassic Park theme music, which does a tremendous job of recreating the  atmosphere of movie.
It's now earlier that day". Your cursor has turned into a magnifying glass  and your scanning the plant-life through a pair of binoculars looking for some elusive triceratops.

Clever Girl

reviewText:
Well this was a fun game to play by Telltale. It was a bit different than the other games from them that I played (Walking Dead 1 and 2, and Back to the Future). As the story goes, you play different characters and there are points in the story where you have to change characters so you can get move to the next phase. Kind of like Lost Vikings, if you remember that game. Then there are action parts where you have to press your arrow keys at precise moments to make the correct move. Again, like the game Dragon's Lair, if anyone is old enogh to remember that in the arcades. It took me a short time to get used to it. You can make mistakes as well, but it will cost you points in a sense there is a gold, silver, and bronze rank for each scenario. You can go back later and redo the scenario and get a better grade. And some achievements need to have certain desicions as well. Again, you'd have to go back and play the scenario and make the second desicion to get the other achievement.

The downside of this game is that it's really short. 4 chapters and I finished it in 9 hours. So it would be wise for this game to get it on sale, because it may be fun, but I don't believe it's worth the full price. Aside from that the only other thing is it COULD be buggey. It lags a bit so I don't know if it's on my end or the game. Let's just say, I don't have any other problems with any of my other games.

But aside from the minor downside, it is entertaining and fun to play. So enjoy.

reviewText:
The main reason I'm writing this review is that there are A LOT of negative reviews here and I feel they're not justified. This is a really good game. And if you're a fan of Jurassic Park, it's even a GREAT game.

However, it has an extremely QTE-oriented gameplay, even by Telltale Games standards. Which is probably why there are so many negative reviews: if you don't like this type of gameplay and you really didn't expect it then of course, the game is going to come off bad.

The story is wonderful, very close in style (and reflection) to the book, although I'll admit there are some pretty cheasy plot twists. The graphics now look a bit outdated but not bad enough to affect gameplay. Most of the characters are very enjoyable, the voice acting is pretty decent (which, along with the QTE gameplay sometimes gives you the impression you're playing a movie... if that makes any sense to you). And, of course, the soundtrack is awesome (gotta love that intro).

The steam achievments are easy enough to get 100% as well, if you're that kind of player :)

reviewText:
Jurassic Park: The Game could of been so much better. For those of you looking for the writing and edge of your seat moments of The Walking Dead series, you'll be dissapointed. You won't find them in this game.

The first major issue would obviously be the gameplay, which is entirely driven by QTEs. They're not that hard but they are constant and become boring very quickly. There is some very minor exploration but that is really just panning across a single screen until you find all the clues, which are highlighted anyway.  You can't control your character but simply jump between scenes at the press of a button. That pretty much sums up the gameplay for you.

For everything else. the writing, characters and graphics are fairly average. Nothing stood out to me. Music is taken straight from the movie, I can't remember hearing any original music at all. Some people might prefer that but I didn't. At times I would get an annoying glitch with the sound which added a echo effect to all the voices and some sound effects.

Overall this game doesn't offer anything interesting to a Jurassic Park fan or even an adventure game fan. For hardcore Jurassic Park fans who are going to play this no matter what, like me, I would definitely say wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Episode 1: good and standard Telltale storytelling and gameplay 8/10 (good)
Episode 2: ruins everything built up in the first episode and essentially kills the game 4/10 (bad)
Episode 3: a mix of bad and good action and dialogue scenes 6/10 (ok)
Episode 4: excessive and mostly pointless dialogue, but the game ends decently 7/10 (pretty good)

Telltale did a good job in implementing references to the first Jurassic Park movie and fans will get a nice nostalgia feeling.  The graphics of the game and the voice acting is also good.  But the QTE gameplay is poorly implemented and excessive, why do I need QTE for walking down a flight of stairs?  The dialogue and storytelling is inconsistent, with some strange plot twists and pointless back stories.

I can recommend only the first episode, after that just stop playing the game.  Overall, there are much better Telltale games and story rich games out there to play, so just avoid Jurassic Park: The Game.

reviewText:
The Egregious:

As far as QTE laden games go Jurassic Park The Game has to rank among the absolute worst.  The QTEs are the game play and are poorly designed, poorly implemented, poorly placed, sometimes make no sense and are poorly explained.  Gaming wise JPTG is an epic catastrophe that  deserves it's own pillar in the gaming hall of shame.  This is a work that could of been something much greater.

The Redeeming:

If you're a fan of a decent dinosaur tale and don't mind watching the death scene after death scene as you fail QTE after QTE you might want to give it a spin.  Some of the death representations are laughably side splitting and ludicrously enjoyable, so much so that I looked forward to and did not care to fail the QTE sequences.  The dinosaurs are the one awesome and redeeming aspect of JPTG.  They are awesome in every respect.  They look realistic, behave realisticly thanks to their great modelling and animation.  The dinosaurs save Jurassic Park The Game and it is on this one merit that I can recommend what I would otherwise classify as a classic gaming disaster.

reviewText: This game is laughably bad. I still liked it, but it's a terrible example of a good game. Though it is no Trespasser, this game does terrible things with the Jurassic Park franchise the least of which being having a blatant Vasquez from Aliens ripoff. As far as story goes, the characters actions and events surrounded them seem to jump dramatically between being painfully predictable (The annoying shmutt with the flashlight's demise.) and utterly devoid of logic. (Raptor knife fight, sitting on a Rexy's face, you get the idea.)\n\nIt's really bizarre how downright bad the storytelling is though, considering Telltales recent endeavors with the Walking Dead and Wolfman series which have been excellent! They seemed to work out all the kinks in their story telling style here. This game is like seeing all the crappy 3rd grade crayon level drawings Leonardo da Vinci must of done before painting the Mona Lisa. On one hand, I'm glad they worked it out so that Walking Dead and Wolfman could be so good, but on the other I wish they didn't butcher Jurassic Park to do it.

reviewText:
Holy crap, stay away from this game.
I finished the whole game and by the end of it I was so mad (and I had a killer headache).
Notes: QTE stands for Quick Time Events"

Jurassic Park: The Game is an adventure story which has one game play element
hoursPlayed:
I hate filling a cut scene with some interactive "Press X to not die" but having a whole game hinging on this pathetic excuse for interactivity is down right dreadful.

My biggest problem with this is that it takes you out of the game. Unlike seeing that you need to move or duck or jump the game shouts at you "You're holding a controller! Press the blue button on the controller to do some special thing!"

Also
voteText: the game's sound is REALLY buggy. In the first scene in the game the audio was bugging out and the characters kept repeating their lines over and over again. Also
helpfulPercent: there were times when you would hear a strange echo even though there was no reason for one (specially at the end or episode 4).\n\nNow
votesHelpful: when I say poorly done I'm not saying that it's just that they are frequent. Nope
votesTotal: they are actually technically poor. When the "Press the X button" icon jumps up on the screen if you mis-press the button it actually immediately fails. This would be a pain enough
votesFunny: but when you're told to move your thumb stick in a direction it's possible to accidentally hit the detection for the wrong direction failing you out.\n\nAlso
commentsCount: for some reason it was decided that the standard fair of QTE's wasn't enough. This game has complex button pressing. Sure
column16:
you'll find the average button mashing (press a button a bazillion times until a meter is full) and the button holding (press and hold a button until the meter is full) but this game had the HORRIBLE idea of combining those two so you actually have to hold both bumpers WHILE pumping a button until a meter is full.

There are also FOUR button combos which if you mis-press any of them in the split second you get to react you die.

My only happiness came at the end of the credits.

Tell Tale is the king of adventure games (second only to double fine) but Jurassic Park the game is something that should have stayed extinct."

reviewText:
Jurassic Park The Game is a cinematic adventure divided into four-episodes. It is full of Quick-Time-Events with a story that smartly expands on that of the movie.
The events of Jurassic Park The Game run parallel to those of the first film, starting soon after Dennis Nedryâ€™s unfortunate run-in with the dilophosaurus. While he is out of the picture before the game begins, his can of Barbasol, loaded with dinosaur embryos, plays a major role in the game. Jurassic Park The Game follows a group of survivors left on the island after having missed the evacuation boat during the storm that knocked out the power in the park. These include the park's veterinarian and his visiting daughter, a jilted geneticist who cares more about dinosaurs than people, the mysterious woman sent to steal dinosaur embryos and a few mercenaries to rescue the stragglers.
Each of the characters has a backstory that the player learns more about as the game progresses, but most of the characters are so unlikable that it is difficult to care.
Jurassic Park The Game consits of two types of sections: action sequences and puzzle sequences. The action sequences consist entirely of quick time events. The worst offenders are the double or triple arrow quick time events. It is unfairly difficult the first time, but then stupidly easy the second time, and it gives the player no satisfaction.
Following the lead of the boring action sequences, the puzzle sequences require virtually no thinking. Most are solved by clicking all the investigate icons until something happens.
There are a few graphical glitches, but overall, the environments and the dinosaurs look fine.
Locations, sound effects and music from the movie are good used.
I can not recommend it to anybody, except hardcore fans of Jurassic Park. There are a lot of better point and click adventure games. Jurassic Park the game is not worth the full price.

Sound 8/10
Graphics 6/10
Gameplay 2/10
Atmosphere 5/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:
http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guides
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curation

reviewText:
I rather enjoyed this game, but I'm a huge fan of the Jurassic Park franchise so I am most likely rather biased.
The story itself was pretty good, though some of the characters were insanely predictable in regards to their actions. Aside from that, the story moves along rather smoothly and has some rather interesting ways of puzzle solving as may of Telltales' games do. The animation style is lovely, and I'm rather pleased that there are many different animations depending on the way you make your choices and how you end up dying. Also, this game has an excellent soundtrack, though it uses a lot of the original music from the films.

I would say that the time you're given to make decisions/press action buttons is a bit too short. It's rather difficult to end up with a gold ranking with a lot of the more action packed bits of the game. I can see from my previous playthrough of The Walking Dead series that Telltale has adjusted and made it a bit easier, but it was still extremely frustrating to die so many times.

8/10 from me!

Here's to hoping that Telltale will get the rights to make another game once Jurassic World is out!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As much as I adore the Jurassic Park franchise, my view of this game is paticularly negative.

The gameplay is rather bland. You're limited to mainly quicktime events and point-and-click adventure/puzzle-solving scenarios. It's essentially like Telltale's The Walking Dead, where you're mainly watching an interactive movie, but unlike Telltale's amazing zombie game, many of your choices do not affect how the story will play out.

The story isn't that great either. Being that its gameplay is rather mediocre, one would expect for the story to make up for it, but it doesn't. Despite expanding on Jurassic Park, the game has an average to low quality of story.

Overall, Telltale's Jurassic Park feels more like a B-movie than an actual game, with the only difference being that every once in a while you need to complete a quicktime event, otherwise you'll be forced to rewind back a couple of seconds and start over.

reviewText:
I love Jurassic Park, but I didn't entirely love this game.

I really only got halfway through the game (PICK UP THE CAN, BILLY!), but even so it left a bitter taste in my mouth.  Quick-time events chained together by environmental point-and-click puzzles became the Telltale's trademark with the Walking Dead series, but this was their clunky first step in that direction (Telltale had previously only had point-and-click followups or remakes of certain Lucasarts adventure titles) The voice acting tends to swing from good to terrible and the story isn't all that great. It's nice to see more of Isla Nublar than what was seen in the movie, even if it's while you're frantically tapping buttons to run away from a Tyrannosaurus Rex. It ties in clumsily with the movie series, so I guess it's okay it's only partially canon.
I really only give this my recommendation based on gameplay footage of the final chapter (the point at which Telltale actually started getting the hang of the QTE-based action) where the quick time events really lend themselves to the urgent urgency (If you realize I just quoted Ian Malcolm, good for you) of the situation at hand (Get to the boat, don't get eaten by the motherf*ckin' T-Rex!) and Nima's subplot was nicely done (if you should decide to listen) and worthy of a re-review.
I give Telltale's Jurassic Park: The Game a 7/10
It's not what I wanted out of a Jurassic Park game, it's got its problems, but it manages to get past these obstacles and  expand on the movie's story (even if it isn't canon anymore)  without having to involve the movie's original cast

reviewerDisplayName: â˜† â™¥ Shane Long â™¥ â˜†
reviewText:
â™šJurassic Park: The Gameâ™š
6/23/15

â™¥Jurassic Park: The Game is an episodic graphic adventure based on the Jurassic Park film franchise.
The gameplay is never the equal of the inspiration though. There are three basic scenarios you'll have to deal with, but the combination never clicks. The one closest to Telltale's usual style involves panning the camera around a location, looking for things. You don't have to look very hard, as everything of interest has a big question mark attached, which turns into a magnifying glass so you can click on it. There's no inventory to manage, so all you're really doing is triggering information about the environment or telling characters to open the only door available to them. It looks like a game, but never feels like one.But is more difficult than other Telltales games such as Walking Dead season 1 & 2.
You play as 7 diffrent pepole which is nice,but diologe and character personality are very low sadly.The attempts at human drama are also poorly served by a particularly weak visual style. More realistic than the usual cartoon Telltale approach, yet blighted by jerky animation and freakish facial expressions, it's hard to warm to these crude digital puppets and emotional investment in their plight suffers accordingly.You can hardly blame Telltale for trying something different, given the enormous number of licensed games it's undertaking right now, but Jurassic Park has neither the charm nor ingenuity that the studio is known for. Come the end of the four episodes, each lasting roughly an hour, there's just a strange feeling of emptiness. The game is never interactive enough to make it feel like you've survived a thrilling adventure, nor does it inspire any emotional or intellectual engagement with its characters, situations or story.

But if your a Jurassic Park fan or just love Dinosaurs it's a Must have!â™¥

reviewText: Honestly I dont think this gaem deserves some of the negitive reveiws it has as a bunch of them just complain about the quick time events even when like every telltale game is based around them.But anyways lets get into the reveiw! The game takes place after Jurassic Park and game foucuses on Jerry Harding.If you think you have heard that name before hes the guy from the sick triceratops scene in Jurassic Park.His character devolpent in this game makes him a pretty good protagonist.The other main chararcters consist of his daughter Jess,a woman who used to live on the island before it became Jurassic Park(her name is Nima),and Billy yoder(the antagonist),and some others.Now as your thinking most likey thinking,yes,there are lots of dinosaurs in this game including the infamous Velociraptors and Dilophasaurus,and last but not least the Tyrannosuarus rex.Now the gameplay.It could be better and theirs not really any major decision making exept for one part which I wont spoil.But aside from that the action parts are really fun and the dialog is pretty interesing.And you cant forget the entertaining death scenes!Now finally the story.To say the least it does feel like im playing a Jurassic Park sequal but in video game form. So overall if you love Jurassic Park you will most likely enjoy this,and if you like telltale,you sould also enjoy this, So overall I give it a 8/10! Now be a clever girl(or guy XD)and buy this game!

reviewText:
Frustration Park: The Game
Being a fan of Jurassic Park (the original movie + book), and having played The Walking Dead games, I decided to give this one a go too, despite reading negative reviews here and there.
As it turns out, this was a  BIG  mistake on my part.

I was hoping to get a good story, some decent action and perhaps some crucial decision making, but what I got was:

- Poor cliched story, which doesn't combine well with the movie's plot (since the game is supposed to be set in the same timeline, I think that's relevant). They used plenty of references, but for me it fell flat.

- Extremely annoying and unlikeable characters. (the teenager was perhaps the sole exception) If it wasn't for the fact that I wanted to finish the game, I'd root for the dinosaurs instead (also Gerry Harding was a character in the movie, but he doesn't resemble the movie character in appearance/age. Same as above.)

- Frustrating control system that quickly turns into a quick-time-event-fest; for example a simple task such as walking up a set of stairs or doing some swimming strokes, will require you to tap/smash buttons.

reviewText:
Another game with mixed reviews. I buckled down and bought this during one of Humble Bundle's sales because it was from Telltale. After becoming familiar with the style of Telltale and their Walking Dead game, I decided to try Jurassic Park out because I happen to enjoy the first film. I'm not a hardcore fan. I can't say one way or another if the game is canon and stays true to the film or the novelization, but I will say as a fan of the first film. I enjoyed this immensely.

I wasn't sure what to expect but I wasn't expecting a direct copy of the movie which in my humble opinion it really wasn't. That's a good thing though. Picking up where Dennis left off with the embryos; new contacts were sent to retreive what he had failed to deliver. Meanwhile, there are still other park admins wandering through the park including a father and daughter. The latter left me a little unsettle if you compare it to the film. How could they not know havoc was breaking loose during the time of the storm? In any case, I ignored my curious questions and just rolled with it. By the end of the first episode I was hooked and ended up playing the entire game over four nights to spread out the episodes.

The graphics were pretty amazing. I thought the dinosaurs looked great..and scary! I thought the designers at Telltale did a fabulous job with that. The soundtrack was wonderfully intune with the movie and the ongoings of scenes. I really couldn't have been happier with this game in regards to that. The puzzles aren't really that hard. Some entry codes, but mostly timed controls of evading dinosaurs and such.

I did not experience any bugs or glitches during game play. I am currently running Windows 8.1 on a 64-bit Intel Core i5 with a NVIDIA Geforce graphics card. Probably outdated to most gamers these days but it worked smoothly for me as does any of Telltale's games.

My only gripe is the controls. I chose to use the keyboard even though I did have my Xbox 360 connected. I didn't like how the controls were timed. I really was terrible at that. My timing was always off and would usually leave my characters getting mauled by a T-Rex or a Raptor, which in theory was pretty cool anyway so I'm overlooking that. My stats deal the horrible truth of how bad I am at timing controls and how many times I died throughout the game. Still fun watching everyone get eaten.

Bottom line is if you like Jurassic Park and you like gaming; give the game a try.
Buy it on sale. It's only pocket change.
If you're bad at control timing, enjoy watching the characters get eaten. It's a hoot.

reviewText:
I reviewed this game once when I was younger and... less intelligent. That's a fair way of putting it. I must have gone through this game at least 4 times, and only now do I realize what was wrong with it. This game is divided into 4 chapters, divided amunst at least 3 different writers.

The first chapter of the game has the most movie line references out of all 4 of the chapters. But it's harmless and fun. It even gives us an eery set up to the troodons, who are the main threat built up through the first 3 parts of the game.

Then we have the second and third chapters written by someone else. I'd say these are the best written sections of the game. The second chapter you'll probably find to be the slowest in terms of pacing. The third chapter, however, is great. And if you get this game, it'll be for this quarter of the game, no doubt.

Character development through this point is great. It's probably the only Jurassic Park thing where you'll care about mercenary characters. The plot of the game involves several people getting trapped on the island in tune with the first Jurassic Park, and some iNGen mercs are sent into rescue them. The two we follow on this task, starting with chapter 2, is the wise-cracking Billy Yoder (whose name never gets old to say), and the tatooed muscle, Oscar. The two of them are a great duo, and serve to bring the most fun to the game without making things goofy or tensionless.

The other characters are fine too. You have one of the zookeepers, Dr. Harding, who serves as the game's protagonist. And he has to look after his trouble-making teenage daughter throughout the game. This serves as our family tie in for the movie, like all of the other movies. Then you have a latino chick whose name slips my memory. She's suppose to be tied to Denis Nedry's steal the dino embryos plot; and as such flips between being a good guy and bad guy. And then there's Dr. Sorkin, one of the head researchers with an animal rights activist side. This doesn't become too annoying until the last chapter.

The last chapter is where everything falls apart. It was written by someone entirely different from the other 3 sections of the game, and I think he was either the worst pick possible, or he really hated his collegues. Characters take jaring and cartoonishly dumb twists. It ruins the troodons that were built up as creepy, venomous, noctornal and unseen foes into the same dumb mob lizards as everything else. I shouldn't have felt more tension in the triceratops scene, yet I did. Character deaths are unsatisfying. Plans make no sense. If you're wondering who gave Jurassic World the idea for a mosasaurus, it's this game. Only the one in the movie got more screen time. AND NONE OF THE CHARACTERS IN THAT MOVIE HAD TO SWIM IN A TANK WITH IT. Yet chapter 4 of this game made it boring. My favorite character died. Then someone else makes a complete 180 that makes no sense, and they just turn into a Saturday morning villain. The side plot about the dino embryos became more plot centric than it should have been. And we retcon the movies in a way that makes me want to do the same thing to the writer.

I can't speak for everyone. But I'm willing to bet that most of the negative reviews for this game are largly due to the forth and final chapter of this game. Reguardless of it, I'd still recommend this game for the first 3/4's. 75% may be a C, but I'm willing to say its enough. Wait until this game's for around 50% off or more. If you consider Jurassic Park the greatest movie of all time, this one will give you some joy.

reviewText:
Full price NO hence the thumbs down. On sale, if you like Telltales games and Jurassic Park, then YES, youâ€™ll probably enjoy it! Read on for full review to be prepared for this gameâ€™s shortfalls.
First the bad points, its SHORT, its only 4 episodes and I complete the story in 8 hours and that was with retrying a few sections over and over again, to try and get a perfect gold award for the quick time events.
Which also leads into another bad point, certain quick time events are the standard, press the button the minute it appears on screen, some are, wait until a ring shrinks and goes down and then flashes before pressing the button....now you can imagine and in a game emphasizing speed, quick button pressing, while getting chased by dinos on the screen, instantly just mashes the buttons as they appear only registering that it was a stupid ring version after it its already saying that you missed that quick time event! Another issues, is some you need to pressed one after the other, so for example it might pop up on screen for you to press 'down' and once you press that, it turns instantly into a 'left'. Now 9 times out of 10, this is find you have time to then press the 'left' button but every now and then it only gives you a heartbeat to actually press that second button...so even as your brain is registering 'left' and your finger is pressing 'left' its already said you failed, the only way is to reload and memorising that section and instantly press 'left' after pressing 'down' not even waiting to watch for it to pop up on screen.
Thankfully, it auto saves quite regularly but it still brings us to another issue, now I know this game is basically one long cut-scene but with all this reloading to try and get gold awards you can't skip dialogue! So get ready to hear the same thing over and over again.
Still if your a fan of the films (which is properly the only reason your looking at this game), then your going to enjoy playing not just another story set in the universe of Jurassic Park but with new characters another perspective from the first film. It gives you references at certain points as to where you are in the timeline of the first film.
Sadly this is all happens in the first episode, as your playing, your characters sleep for the night, when they awake, its implied that the film has now ended, leaving just you guys on the island, now I can understand while this was done, to avoid the issue of why didnâ€™t these two groups ever interact in the film but I'm sure I remember a scene in the film, where a certain group spent the night sleeping in a tree!
To me, this feels like a missed opportunity, they could of have more references, maybe stuff that happens in the film interferes in this game characters chances for escape, for example turning the power back on for the fences, could of prevented the characters in the game from linking up with the film characters.
*Slight spoiler alert!*
It also could have made the first episode be stretched out to last 2 or 3 episodes, as sadly the 2nd episode of this is properly the weakest! It introduces more new characters but youâ€™re sat there thinking what are they doing?! Why are they fighting amongst themselves?! And then your like, why arenâ€™t they leaving when they've got the chance?!
Thankfully episode 3 and 4 are better, again its them struggling to either be rescued or get off the island, it almost feels like two different stories if it wasnâ€™t for the episode 2 linking episode 1 and 3/4 together.
Still I enjoyed and to repeat my opening statement, if you like Telltales games and Jurassic Park then youâ€™ll probably enjoy too but only get if and when itâ€™s on Sale.

reviewText:
Jurassic Park: The Game was developed by Telltale and released in 2011. Iâ€™ve been slowly playing my way through it over a number of months. Itâ€™s not a long game but itâ€™s well-suited to being played in small doses.

First, I have to say, I love the movie Jurassic Park. Itâ€™s one of the rare things from childhood that isnâ€™t solely enjoyed through a lens of nostalgia-tinted glasses. Itâ€™s still an exceptional experience for me now. So I might have a better opinion of the game than others who arenâ€™t so taken with it.

Jurassic Park: The Game takes place within the timeline of the first movie, but with completely new characters. When Nedry doesnâ€™t make it to the boat with the dino embryos, a mercenary is sent to retrieve them. Other major characters include the park veterinarian and his daughter and some more mercenaries, sent in by InGen to rescue the people remaining in the park. You play all of these characters â€“ a total of 6 of them â€“ at some point during the game, and the transitions between characters are seamless. Perhaps a little too seamless, as it was sometimes hard to tell when a switch had happened.

Though the story isnâ€™t anything exceptional, itâ€™s true to the spirit of the movie. People being awestruck by dinosaurs and surviving attacks is pretty much the point. The writers are able to create a good amount of tension as each of the main characters have their own, often conflicting motivations. The dialogue sounds natural and the voice acting is competent. The environments are also well done, using replicas of the scenes from the movie, along with some new areas.

While this game adheres to Telltaleâ€™s general oeuvre, itâ€™s also quite different from the more recent releases. The story isnâ€™t as strong, so I didnâ€™t grow attached to any of the characters as I did in The Walking Dead. As a result, JP isnâ€™t soul-crushing like many of the later Telltale Games. It doesnâ€™t make you love characters over the course of a game only to kill them in front of you and make you think itâ€™s your fault for bad decision making. There are decisions to be made, but they arenâ€™t difficult and rarely have the same weight or consequences as a decision in TWD.

In terms of gameplay, I found JP to be a lot more fun than TWD or A Wolf Among Us. Now, I am someone who likes quick time events, so if you donâ€™t you can take this with a grain of salt. JP felt more game-y than the recent Telltale games. There were many more places where you could fail, and more puzzles too. The QTEs could often be quite unforgiving, requiring some very fast twitch reactions, though not every failure resulted in death. Thereâ€™s a medal system for each scenario. No mistakes gave you gold, while if you made many mistakes you could end up with a bronze or no medal at all. These medals didnâ€™t seem to impact anything other than my pride though.  If you fail a critical event, your character dies, but not permanently, you just have to redo it until you succeed.

Though the story and characters arenâ€™t particularly memorable, I enjoyed my time in Jurassic Park. The 4 chapters in the game took a total of about 7-8 hours to complete. I do recommend using a gamepad if youâ€™re playing this on PC, it made the QTEs (with one notable exception) much easier.

Rating: 7/10 â€“ A fun game that captures the spirit of Jurassic Park with a lot of dinosaurs and fast-paced action sequences. Unless you donâ€™t like quick-time events, then you should skip this one.

reviewText:
I didn't think it was so bad.

The story was enjoyable enough, especially for someone who loved the movies and the book. The story, being one of Telltale's early efforts, was enough to keep me interested. Characters weren't terrible but certainly not memorable like they are in The Walking Dead.

The actual playthrough was awful for me though, cutscenes kept starting and stopping, the audio was off a lot of the time, the quicktime events were buggy as hell and sometimes my cursor was missing - all leading to frustration when I was in the middle of trying to avoid getting eaten by dinos. I died more than I should have because of this and it was only because I like seeing things through to the end that I pressed on.

It showed promise, I guess for the games that came after it. I am glad I played it as it showed me a lot of how Telltale developed, both from their early gameplay and character development.

Honestly, unless you are a really big fan of Telltale or Jurassic Park though, I can't recommend it.

reviewerDisplayName: â˜† â™¥ Shane Long â™¥ â˜†
reviewText:
â™šJurassic Park: The Gameâ™š
6/23/15

â™¥Jurassic Park: The Game is an episodic graphic adventure based on the Jurassic Park film franchise.
The gameplay is never the equal of the inspiration though. There are three basic scenarios you'll have to deal with, but the combination never clicks. The one closest to Telltale's usual style involves panning the camera around a location, looking for things. You don't have to look very hard, as everything of interest has a big question mark attached, which turns into a magnifying glass so you can click on it. There's no inventory to manage, so all you're really doing is triggering information about the environment or telling characters to open the only door available to them. It looks like a game, but never feels like one.But is more difficult than other Telltales games such as Walking Dead season 1 & 2.
You play as 7 diffrent pepole which is nice,but diologe and character personality are very low sadly.The attempts at human drama are also poorly served by a particularly weak visual style. More realistic than the usual cartoon Telltale approach, yet blighted by jerky animation and freakish facial expressions, it's hard to warm to these crude digital puppets and emotional investment in their plight suffers accordingly.You can hardly blame Telltale for trying something different, given the enormous number of licensed games it's undertaking right now, but Jurassic Park has neither the charm nor ingenuity that the studio is known for. Come the end of the four episodes, each lasting roughly an hour, there's just a strange feeling of emptiness. The game is never interactive enough to make it feel like you've survived a thrilling adventure, nor does it inspire any emotional or intellectual engagement with its characters, situations or story.

But if your a Jurassic Park fan or just love Dinosaurs it's a Must have!â™¥

reviewText:
One word, craptastic.

After seeing the work Telltale Games has down with the Walking dead it is astounding how they managed to push this out of their company. The quicktime events (if you can call them that) require you to respond within a timeframe that I'm convinced isn't humanly possible except if you: a) memorize the sequence or b) button mash DWAS. The face modeling of reactions and emotions is horrid. Lastly, they have a few bugs to work out with the game suddenly quitting the scenario on you unless you decide to exhaust every possible option on getting back to where you were.

With the negative out of the way I will say this. The journal entries (which are not even part of the gameplay) do a good job of covering up the reasons for why the dinosaurs aren't 100% scientifically faithful. The reasons are well within the story's parameters. The voice acting is also decent at best. However, this two pretty details do not make up for the absolute destitute garbage that is the rest of the game. This game had so much potential but I can't shake the feeling that it was rushed for the sake of catching the media furor that came with the announcement of the Jurassic World.

reviewText:
Jurassic Event: The Quicktime Game
Remember when Telltale Games made games like Sam & Max, Monkey Island and Back to the Future? And have you played any of their recent efforts like The Walking Dead S2, The Wolf Among Us or Tales from the Borderlands?

Ever wondered what happened in between? Well, the answer is: This happened. This very game here. And as such it is a piece of gaming history I would say.

But first things first! As it is, Jurassic Park finds itself in a position which made it a weird game when it came out but also makes it a weird game nowadays. For completely different reasons. How singular is that? I donâ€™t know, but probably very.

When it was released it was a game that had thrown out almost all the things that make a Point 'n Click adventure. No inventory, no items, no walking around, no wild clicking on various things to find solutions to riddles you werenâ€™t even fully aware you were actually trying to solve, very view traditional riddles in general, no manual saving and worst of all no clicking on the same thing dozens of times to hear all the audio bits. Instead it had quicktime events, eventing quicktimes and quickeventing times. And barely anything elseâ€¦

And we all said: Whatâ€™s this supposed to be?

Nowadays, after we have played TWD2, TWAU, TotB and probably even Game of Thrones, we find that it has waaaaaay to much gameplay and not enough swearing, walking around in areas, making decisions that ultimately may or may not mean anything and broken, down-trodden characters.

And we all say: What were they thinking? This dino game is one of the most annoying pieces of software Iâ€™ve ever played!

Now, as a piece of history I think it is fine to play it. Especially so if youâ€™re interested in the development of narrative driven games of the kind that Telltale makes today. Itâ€™s interesting to see that the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ed up characters (if a bit tame though) were already at a place where the gameplay had yet to follow. I was really surprised to see that they even had a child character here that wasn't enervating as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

And as a game on its own? Well, if you like the movie Jurassic Park, this is great. Itâ€™s tied in very, very closely to the events of the movie and expands on quite a few things. The writing is mostly decent or even good, although some parts are brow knottingly silly. But DO NOT expect a classic adventure or a modern Telltale game. Really, do not. So it follows that if you want either such an adventure game or a modern Telltale game then donâ€™t buy this either. Itâ€™s neither of those.

I think you can pay 5 dollars or so for it. Thatâ€™s money well spent for this oddity of gaming history.
