reviewText:
Jurassic Park: The Game was developed by Telltale and released in 2011. Iâ€™ve been slowly playing my way through it over a number of months. Itâ€™s not a long game but itâ€™s well-suited to being played in small doses.

First, I have to say, I love the movie Jurassic Park. Itâ€™s one of the rare things from childhood that isnâ€™t solely enjoyed through a lens of nostalgia-tinted glasses. Itâ€™s still an exceptional experience for me now. So I might have a better opinion of the game than others who arenâ€™t so taken with it.

Jurassic Park: The Game takes place within the timeline of the first movie, but with completely new characters. When Nedry doesnâ€™t make it to the boat with the dino embryos, a mercenary is sent to retrieve them. Other major characters include the park veterinarian and his daughter and some more mercenaries, sent in by InGen to rescue the people remaining in the park. You play all of these characters â€“ a total of 6 of them â€“ at some point during the game, and the transitions between characters are seamless. Perhaps a little too seamless, as it was sometimes hard to tell when a switch had happened.

Though the story isnâ€™t anything exceptional, itâ€™s true to the spirit of the movie. People being awestruck by dinosaurs and surviving attacks is pretty much the point. The writers are able to create a good amount of tension as each of the main characters have their own, often conflicting motivations. The dialogue sounds natural and the voice acting is competent. The environments are also well done, using replicas of the scenes from the movie, along with some new areas.

While this game adheres to Telltaleâ€™s general oeuvre, itâ€™s also quite different from the more recent releases. The story isnâ€™t as strong, so I didnâ€™t grow attached to any of the characters as I did in The Walking Dead. As a result, JP isnâ€™t soul-crushing like many of the later Telltale Games. It doesnâ€™t make you love characters over the course of a game only to kill them in front of you and make you think itâ€™s your fault for bad decision making. There are decisions to be made, but they arenâ€™t difficult and rarely have the same weight or consequences as a decision in TWD.

In terms of gameplay, I found JP to be a lot more fun than TWD or A Wolf Among Us. Now, I am someone who likes quick time events, so if you donâ€™t you can take this with a grain of salt. JP felt more game-y than the recent Telltale games. There were many more places where you could fail, and more puzzles too. The QTEs could often be quite unforgiving, requiring some very fast twitch reactions, though not every failure resulted in death. Thereâ€™s a medal system for each scenario. No mistakes gave you gold, while if you made many mistakes you could end up with a bronze or no medal at all. These medals didnâ€™t seem to impact anything other than my pride though.  If you fail a critical event, your character dies, but not permanently, you just have to redo it until you succeed.

Though the story and characters arenâ€™t particularly memorable, I enjoyed my time in Jurassic Park. The 4 chapters in the game took a total of about 7-8 hours to complete. I do recommend using a gamepad if youâ€™re playing this on PC, it made the QTEs (with one notable exception) much easier.

Rating: 7/10 â€“ A fun game that captures the spirit of Jurassic Park with a lot of dinosaurs and fast-paced action sequences. Unless you donâ€™t like quick-time events, then you should skip this one.

reviewText:
I didn't think it was so bad.

The story was enjoyable enough, especially for someone who loved the movies and the book. The story, being one of Telltale's early efforts, was enough to keep me interested. Characters weren't terrible but certainly not memorable like they are in The Walking Dead.

The actual playthrough was awful for me though, cutscenes kept starting and stopping, the audio was off a lot of the time, the quicktime events were buggy as hell and sometimes my cursor was missing - all leading to frustration when I was in the middle of trying to avoid getting eaten by dinos. I died more than I should have because of this and it was only because I like seeing things through to the end that I pressed on.

It showed promise, I guess for the games that came after it. I am glad I played it as it showed me a lot of how Telltale developed, both from their early gameplay and character development.

Honestly, unless you are a really big fan of Telltale or Jurassic Park though, I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Frustration Park: The Game
Being a fan of Jurassic Park (the original movie + book), and having played The Walking Dead games, I decided to give this one a go too, despite reading negative reviews here and there.
As it turns out, this was a  BIG  mistake on my part.

I was hoping to get a good story, some decent action and perhaps some crucial decision making, but what I got was:

- Poor cliched story, which doesn't combine well with the movie's plot (since the game is supposed to be set in the same timeline, I think that's relevant). They used plenty of references, but for me it fell flat.

- Extremely annoying and unlikeable characters. (the teenager was perhaps the sole exception) If it wasn't for the fact that I wanted to finish the game, I'd root for the dinosaurs instead (also Gerry Harding was a character in the movie, but he doesn't resemble the movie character in appearance/age. Same as above.)

- Frustrating control system that quickly turns into a quick-time-event-fest; for example a simple task such as walking up a set of stairs or doing some swimming strokes, will require you to tap/smash buttons.
Gets  really  tedious very early in the game.

- In relation to previous point, the achievements, if one cares about those (I'm no fanatic, but in general it can be motivating), timing a quick time event wrong, will cause you too lose out on quite a few achievements(requirement of flawless/without slip ups" in certain segments of the game.)

reviewText:
Oh man, I love you Telltale, I really do, but this is a mess.

Let's start with the objective faults. There are game problems. These include minor issues, such as choosing the resolution sets the resolution at the same time, so if you're at say 640x480, and you want to get to 1920x1080, your monitor is going to pass through about 15 resolutions before you get there. This is annoying and there is no need for it, and should really be patched out.

Space, for some crazy reason, functions like the escape key in most games. The game is poorly optimised so if you happen to press it, expect a good 5 seconds until you're back in the game.

Many a time for whatever reason the mouse icon was lost off the screen. Sometimes the only way to fix it was to quit the game entirely.

The plot and storyline is, passable, but not as brilliant as say, the remarkable Wolf Among Us or Walking Dead series.

But the quick time events. Oh man. The QTEs are where the fault in this game is 100%. Even with all the other problems, they pale into insignificance to the problem of the QTEs.

The QTEs have compound buttons on many occasions, such as Left then Down. However, the timing is instant, so if you don't hit it straight away, you fail. The game does not give you enough time to actually see the QTE before failing the QTE, and a single fail means you lose Gold" rating. Further
date: these all occour in the high action story points of the game.\n\nSo what should be the action highlights of the game
hoursPlayed: just leave you frustrated and angered as you see fail after fail and reload trying for that Gold and perfect QTE sequence. You'll start to repeat the mantra. Right down right right up up down right as you memorise a level's QTEs for the gold. Finish it and then move onto the next level to start again. Left up left down right up right......\n\nPoorly executed game with some of the worst QTEs that I've ever seen in gaming. Only for dedicated Jurassic Park fans. Skip this
voteText: and go get The Wolf Among Us if you haven't."

reviewText:
I came to this game (lured by a Steam sale) after years of warnings that it was garbage. A misstep, an unfortunate footnote in Telltale's path to greatness. While undeniably not as polished as, say, The Walking Dead, it is absolutely worth playing if you're a serious fan of either Telltale or the Jurassic Park franchise.

THE STORY
The Game takes the ending of the first Jurassic Park movie to some interesting places with the story of those left behind after Hammond & Co. were evacuated. Some of the philosophical questions of genetic engineering that get brushed past in the movie are given a lot more consideration here. The characters are mostly well-drawn and develop in interesting and unexpected ways as the game goes on. There's even a kid in it who isn't completely annoying! More than can be said for most of the movies. The affection and respect the dev team had for the franchise is apparent all the details they get right, from the Isla Nublar-shaped road signs and InGen-logoed steam pipes to the dinosaur sounds and music cues lifted straight from the movie. There are a few ideas in The Game borrowed from other parts of the JP universe, including Michael Crichton's books, which is fun to see. There's even a journal with unlockable content that charmingly retcons some of the paleontological inaccuracies of the first movie.

THE GAMEPLAY
There are a lot more quicktime events than in later Telltale games. It arguably suits the action-oriented JP franchise but yes, it can be a little frustrating, especially if you're an achievement completionist trying to perfect every scenario". The action scenes feel genuinely thrilling
date:
though. The puzzle sections aren't as hard as the QTEs and are fairly intuitive to figure out.

PRESENTATION
There are a few quirks that mark this as a learning experience for Telltale. There are some odd volume glitches. The graphics aren't cutting-edge
recommended: even for a 2011 point-and-click adventure. The graphics settings menu
hoursPlayed: bizarrely
voteText: requires you to change the screen resolution as you cycle through the options. The most irritating thing may be that when retrying the QTE scenarios to get better medals some of them dump you in way before any action starts. You have to sit through minutes of cutscene before you get to try again. Grrr. None of this is game-breaking
helpfulPercent: though. The voice acting
votesHelpful: crucially
votesTotal: is top-notch
votesFunny: supporting a well-written script. The animation of the dinosaurs and motion-captured humans is pretty good (for a game of its type - we're not talking CryEngine stuff here) and the cinematography is engaging and cinematic
commentsCount: if not quite Spielbergian.\n\nIn summary
column16: Jurassic Park: The Game is better than you've heard. I can't recommend it to the casual gamer who gets easily frustrated with QTE/narrative-based games but If you've played Walking Dead
column17: Wolf Among Us and Game of Thrones it's worth going back to see this step in the evolution of Telltale Games. And if you're a big Jurassic Park fan it comes highly recommended
column18: expanding on the lore in much more interesting and mature ways than the Jurassic World movie did. Now THAT was one big pile of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥."

reviewText:
Given that this game is narrative based, I feel that a cinematic style is one of the most important aspects of the game.  However, depending on how the game is played, and how much skill one has in the realm of quick time decision making, the game can get a little jumbled.

I will start off by saying that I really do enjoy the game, and it has been a fairly entertaining experience, the parallel story presented in this game along side the events of Jurassic Park (1993) works fairly well. The game has a nice atmosphere and it looks good most of the time. I also find that the characters are pretty likeable, and the dialogue is fairly fluent and natural sounding as well. Though there are some continuity and contradiction issues in regard to the dialogue, nothing too distracting, however.

The game isn't exactly perfect. Instant respawns on death with little to no penalty give minimal consequence to actions, something that another more recent title, Until Dawn, exceeds at, leaving me feeling a little disappointed. Since I pretty much suck at all quick-time-event games, dying really distrupts the flow of the game at certain points as well.  The actual gameplay during action sequences can get a little sketchy too, I found that I died at least ten times in roughly two minutes, this may be attributed to the fact that I am really not that great at qte.

Overall, I believe that the positives outweigh the negatives (some of which are purely situational) in Jurassic Park: The Game, and the gameplay isn't really that bad, I enjoyed some of the light mystery solving, and of course, the dinosaurs. I don't think that this game is worth its full price however, I got it 75% off.  I think anyone who likes a decent story and is a fan of the film will enjoy this title.

7/10

reviewText:
If you love quick time events then you'll love Jurassic Park: The Game.

What's that? You DON'T love quick time events? Nobody does? Oh, well there may be a problem here.

Look I love Jurassic Park and this one is kind of cool. The nods to the 1993 film, the minimal cross-over, (although to be honest I wanted more,) the plot and the action are all good. The plot is actually pretty much what I thought The Lost World" would be when I was a kid and went to see that. The dialogue seems kind of hammy at first but admittedly gives the feel of early-90s Spielberg. But while some of the problem-solving puzzles are fun enough
date: having an action scene being basically ruined by being forced to hit keys at various times just isn't fun and doesn't make you feel any more involved in the action. You kind of just wish you had the option of just sitting back and watching it all unfold instead.\n\nThis felt like Jurassic Park and in that it was good. It just wasn't fun to play"

reviewText:
John waits patiently for unskippable cut scene to end.
John chooses series of dialogue options, each initiating an unskippable dialogue scene.
Moments before the game should auto-save, game crashes.
John reboots PC, just to be safe, then reloads game.
John waits impatiently for the same unskippable cut scene that he just watched to end.
John instinctively mashes the ESC key to skip unskippable cut scene.
Main menu comes up, but there's an excruciating delay before John can resume game.
John resumes game, but now his mouse cursor has disappeared, forcing him to fumble his way through the scene.
Game auto-saves and John restarts the game AGAIN in order to get his cursor back, a process that he's required to repeat multiple times during his ten hours with buggy game.
John becomes irritated that game accomplishes the same thing that Jurassic Park 3 managed to... Make some of the greatest predators who have ever lived seem feeble, harmless and easily defeated by a group of nerds and a 13 year old girl.
John finishes poorly-designed game, writes grumpy review, quietly uninstalls bad game and never speaks of it again.

reviewText: Loved the movies (especially 1 and 2), and I love this game. It picks up moments before the ending of the first movie. The game itself is focused on the story and gameplay elemtents mainly consists of puzzels, looking around and picking dialogue options. The story itself seems to be abit more lineair then the more recent telltale titles like The Walking Dead, but it still has various dialogue options. The more frantic moments are accompanied by quick time events. Those QTE's are sometimes a bit too abrupt, and not very clear to me untill after my character got mulched to bits (but rarely). Abit short but all in all a good game. Would be awesome if Telltale would make a similair game around The Lost World. I can recommend this to telltale and jurassic park fans alike.

reviewText:
Its hit and miss. One of these reviews were its hard to say positive or negative, its right between.

Pros:

+ an original story
+ interesting characters
+ to a degree interactive
+ cool action scenes
+ alternative ending
+ controller support
+ Nvidia 3D is fantastic!
+ a lenghty story with 7,5 hours. Compare this to a 2 hour movie with the same price tagg, you definitely get your moneys worth (for a sale price at least)

Cons:

- 28â‚¬? I think thats too expensive, but on the other hand a blueray costs the same amount for less content. At sale its perfect
- QTEs timeframes are sometimes extremely short and impossible to get on the first try
- the rating system (bronze, silver, gold) is kinda pointless. I just wanna enjoy the story and its very distracting and only worsen the experience of enjoying the adventure and story
- some plotholes, but most movies have some
- ....its more a movie than a game, even though it has Game" in the title its totally another movie.
- almost no choice throughout the whole movie. Its just QTEs and pressing the right buttons to progress
date: not to make choices. They trick you with dialouge choices
recommended: but they dont matter at all. Sometimes you can even fail a QTE and the movie will still go on

reviewText: Honestly I dont think this gaem deserves some of the negitive reveiws it has as a bunch of them just complain about the quick time events even when like every telltale game is based around them.But anyways lets get into the reveiw! The game takes place after Jurassic Park and game foucuses on Jerry Harding.If you think you have heard that name before hes the guy from the sick triceratops scene in Jurassic Park.His character devolpent in this game makes him a pretty good protagonist.The other main chararcters consist of his daughter Jess,a woman who used to live on the island before it became Jurassic Park(her name is Nima),and Billy yoder(the antagonist),and some others.Now as your thinking most likey thinking,yes,there are lots of dinosaurs in this game including the infamous Velociraptors and Dilophasaurus,and last but not least the Tyrannosuarus rex.Now the gameplay.It could be better and theirs not really any major decision making exept for one part which I wont spoil.But aside from that the action parts are really fun and the dialog is pretty interesing.And you cant forget the entertaining death scenes!Now finally the story.To say the least it does feel like im playing a Jurassic Park sequal but in video game form. So overall if you love Jurassic Park you will most likely enjoy this,and if you like telltale,you sould also enjoy this, So overall I give it a 8/10! Now be a clever girl(or guy XD)and buy this game!

reviewText:
I didn't think it was so bad.

The story was enjoyable enough, especially for someone who loved the movies and the book. The story, being one of Telltale's early efforts, was enough to keep me interested. Characters weren't terrible but certainly not memorable like they are in The Walking Dead.

The actual playthrough was awful for me though, cutscenes kept starting and stopping, the audio was off a lot of the time, the quicktime events were buggy as hell and sometimes my cursor was missing - all leading to frustration when I was in the middle of trying to avoid getting eaten by dinos. I died more than I should have because of this and it was only because I like seeing things through to the end that I pressed on.

It showed promise, I guess for the games that came after it. I am glad I played it as it showed me a lot of how Telltale developed, both from their early gameplay and character development.

Honestly, unless you are a really big fan of Telltale or Jurassic Park though, I can't recommend it.

reviewText: By many measures, an enjoyable game experience that rises above its faults and limitations.  Jurassic Park: The Game by Telltale Games lacks many of the qualities that have made their more recent games so successful, but when viewed by itself; stands as a solid dinosaur-themed adventure.\n\nExpect something akin to a visual novel with button rhythm elements and plenty of tension.  You could likely play through the story in approximately 6 hours, but you'll get a lot more out of your purchase if you're an achievement junky.  There are some bugs that aren't going to go away and some of them inadvertently make achievement hunting more frustrating than it should be, but it's far from game-breaking.  The going rate of $19.99 is probably asking too much at this point, but for $8.00 or so this is a worthwhile pick-up for anyone who likes to be chased by dinos and/or prefers their games heavy on story-telling.

reviewText: Another Telltale game that I really liked, although it's a bit of a pain to figure out ways around bugs! Once you're able to get around the first major bug (cursor disappearing and refusing to come back without either reloading or restarting the game), then the minor bug (cursor disappearing) in the rest of the game is a cakewalk. It would be nice to get the bug fixed.\n\nHowever, I liked that this was based around Jurassic Park and loved how it connected itself to the movie. I would definitely buy this game ONLY if you can get a really good deal and HIGHLY recommend reading the discussion boards to help with the bugs. Although, if you don't want to be bothered by bugs, I'd pass on this game.

reviewText:
Game centered around advertising Barbasol shaving cream. I'm not sure how much they paid, but it must have been a large sum.

The game itself likely lasts around 2 hours, however you will spend six hours on it due lengthy animations retrying to get past death scenes.

90% of the story is a stretch. For example, you unlock a locked, key-coded door by placing a picture on a wall.

Noone in this game actually had to die if they would have waited around for dinos to leave.

This game made me more misogynistic.

Only reason I suggest this game is because you are probably bored looking for a game to fill the void that BF2 predecessors left.

Get this through Humble Bundle.

Worth $5-10 tops.

reviewText: While most of action in the game was as about as believable as your typical action flick (meaning that no way could anyone have actually survived if this was real), it was still fun to play through. The story told in the setting of the Jurassic Park movie/book is origingal, though completely based around the well-known and loved story. As far as I could tell, not many choices actually change the story other than some dialog options and sadly it doesn't let you compare your choices to those of others. It's an adventure game, meaning that it's really based on story more than skill, though sometimes pressing buttons exactly right required me to try several times (I did a lot of dying). There are also fun acheievements to unlock as you go to keep things interesting. I'd say that compared to The Walking Dead games by Telltale, which I gave 5/5 stars, this gets a 4/5 stars. It's super fun and definitately intense, though there were only a few moral dilemas. I felt like some of the puzzles" one had to solve were just space/time fillers
recommended: I dislike puzzles and prefer drama more. It kind of felt like we were forced into various puzzles that felt silly.\nBottom line: I recommend this game to anyone who likes adventure games that are based on story

reviewText:
I wanted to get through Jurassic Park: The Game before reviewing it, but I could not. Of the three parts, I arrived at the third part before my patience wtih this game ran out. It's less adventure game, more Quick Time Events: The Game.

The tutorial explains half of the controls -- but not what the Directional Pad does or how to handle the commands with teh slowly shrinking circles. The former changes locations and the latter must be pressed AFTER the otuer circle connects with the inner circle. Not all of the command prompts stay on the screen long enough for you to complete the action. If you're going for gold medals in all of the segments, good luck to you. I'm sharing these so that you might find some enjoyment in the game where I could not.

That said, if you want to see what it's like to witness your characters falling prey to dinosaurs, I hope you never get tired of seeing it. You will see it happen a lot.

reviewText:
QTE's are awfull.
The music is very good and nostalgic, and it's easy to finish an episode in 1.5 to 2 hours. With a total of 4 episodes it doesn't take long to finish.
The story, despite being simple and just a bit bland, is a good sequel to Jurasssic Park itself. It's very linear and decision making have no real impact on later events but that and QTE's aside I enjoyed myself.

The dinosaurs were awesome. Seriously the dinosaurs really made it all up to me. Especially the big ones.

In short it's mediocre game, wouldn't reccomend it for full price. But it can be a fun time waster and dino's are awesome.

reviewText:
Game centered around advertising Barbasol shaving cream. I'm not sure how much they paid, but it must have been a large sum.

The game itself likely lasts around 2 hours, however you will spend six hours on it due lengthy animations retrying to get past death scenes.

90% of the story is a stretch. For example, you unlock a locked, key-coded door by placing a picture on a wall.

Noone in this game actually had to die if they would have waited around for dinos to leave.

This game made me more misogynistic.

Only reason I suggest this game is because you are probably bored looking for a game to fill the void that BF2 predecessors left.

Get this through Humble Bundle.

Worth $5-10 tops.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Another Telltale game that I really liked, although it's a bit of a pain to figure out ways around bugs! Once you're able to get around the first major bug (cursor disappearing and refusing to come back without either reloading or restarting the game), then the minor bug (cursor disappearing) in the rest of the game is a cakewalk. It would be nice to get the bug fixed.\n\nHowever, I liked that this was based around Jurassic Park and loved how it connected itself to the movie. I would definitely buy this game ONLY if you can get a really good deal and HIGHLY recommend reading the discussion boards to help with the bugs. Although, if you don't want to be bothered by bugs, I'd pass on this game.

reviewText: Has massive technical problems - audio bugs out from time to time, graphical glitches, controls sometimes not responsive and sometimes the game will repeat dialogues twice. Even if you look past that, it's a big quicktime event mess with sometimes ridiculous moments. And the one thing that Telltale games are based around - the story is generic and forgettable. There's nothing I can recommend about this one.

reviewText: The game was pretty much what I was expecting - a mostly QTE-based interactive movie with a few puzzles and an interesting and entertaining story. There's a few minor bugs throughout - very rarely the voice audio would spike in volume for a second, and a couple of times the camera jumped around in an unexpected way - but nothing that prevented me from becoming engrossed in the story and gameplay. I recommend it if you like interactive movies, Telltale Games or you want to be told another story in the Jurassic Park world.

reviewText: The Jurassic Park by Telltale was bought with great expectations since I have played their other titles such as The Walking Dead and Game of Thrones. I would like to say it lives upto the Telltale standards, but it does not, which is fine, because I do believe it is an earlier effort at making story games from franchises. Regardless, it is a reasonably fun game though not that deep in terms of character development and writing.

reviewText:
Let me put it this way...

The Lego Jurassic World game version is much, much better than this corny piece of crap. As a hardcore fan of the novels and movies, I feel Telltale have horribly ruined the concept of Jurassic Park. I cringed the entire way through this very long cartoon. So disappointed in this game.

--> The graphics is like I said, a cartoon.

--> The animation is really bad. I mean REALLY bad. It's still VERY glitchy.

--> The dinosaurs are portrayed as unrealistically stupid and slow. This goes especially for the raptors and T-rex.

--> The writing behind this game is a joke.

--> Quick Time Events are the devil. This type of gameplay forces you to become disengaged from the story since you are constantly on edge in case you miss a button press. (If they show, still buggy)

The game is basically a cartoon to watch. There's no control. It's entirely QTE. You might as well watch this on YouTube.

To save youself some money, watch the game here. It's pretty much the same thing:

https://youtu.be/7O7hiJnPHUM
